"', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1538229522000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'3684556', u'in_reply_to': u'120962572', u'id': u'120964350', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'JamesValencia', u'text': u'Hi, thanks for the long response:
1) "It seems to me that most of the people who think they are 'experts' are climate change deniers" - I agree. Most experts on here won't say "I'm an expert" which is correct. Dogmatic commentators, however, will tend to say "I'm right because I am etc., etc."I've had long discussions with persons trying to winkle my profile out of me, for example, which I won't do: it's pointless since there's no verification possible.
2) The problem with "this bit of pedantry" is that this is a public understanding of science, and though Abraham's right in what he says, it's not well put.That's the point, and that is not pedantry.The use of "melting ice can cause..." is OK if he's talking to scientists and not OK in the popular press. I'd suggest being straight right from the start: "Ice on land melting and flowing into the sea raises sea levelt".
It's not critical, but reading this article I also thought, before I read robertpinker's comment, that JA was less good this time than usual.
And therefore I agree rather than automatically defending J. Abrahams :)
That also covers the point about certainty, which also goes to the heart of this spat concerning RP saying "avoid "can" mr. Abrahams!" :
A problem I see very often is the popular understanding of science getting sidetracked into false questions. 
The biggest example is "Did global warming cause suchandsuch a cyclone / flooding / event ?"
It's not a meaningful question. And the tendency by scientists to engage with it is a mistake. We see articles saying "Well, the warming made this event more likely, by so much, and so we think this one we can state unequivocally that global warming is a contributing factor. This other one, we can't tell exactly because it's somewhere else and the factors etc., etc., etc."
The answer should be: "Global warming has increased sea tempertures by X which has led to heat flux as far as we can tell increasing by Y - see this map here - and that means that atmorpheric water content has increased by Z and circulation by A and the result of that is more water, more circulation, more heat in the atmosphere and all these increases definitely increase the frequency and power of storms, there's no doubt about it.Asking about a particular storm is a stupid question, it's as pointless as asking if a particular snowflake falling in December is the result of evaporation from a river, or an ocean, or a lake: Some questions are the wrong question to ask."
Voilà :)', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1538227224000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u'i am etc', u'effect': u"i 'm right"}, {u'cause': u'the use of ice', u'effect': None}, {u'cause': u"exactly it 's somewhere else and the factors etc", u'effect': u"this other one we ca n't tell etc"}], u'author_id': u'3761271', u'in_reply_to': u'120957573', u'id': u'120963561', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'chrisbrown', u'text': u'Here is Wiki's explanation of how the system on the struts for the Alaska pipeline work:"in the Trans-Alaska Pipeline System residual ground heat remaining in the oil as well as heat produced by friction and turbulence in the moving oil could conduct down the pipe's support legs and melt the permafrost on which the supports are anchored. This would cause the pipeline to sink and possibly be damaged. To prevent this, each vertical support member has been mounted with four vertical heat pipe thermosyphons.[39]
The significant feature of a thermosyphon is that it is passive and does not require any external power to operate. During the winter, the air is colder than the ground around the supports. The liquid ammonia at the bottom of the thermosyphon is vaporized by heat absorbed from the ground, cooling the surrounding permafrost and lowering its temperature. During the summer, the thermosyphons stop operating, since there is no liquid ammonia available at the top of the heat pipe, but the extreme cooling during the winter allows the ground to remain frozen."', u'recommendation_count': u'4', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1538128112000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u'this', u'effect': u'the pipeline to sink and possibly be damaged'}], u'author_id': u'3684556', u'in_reply_to': u'120934388', u'id': u'120934531', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'TTauriStellarbody', u'text': u'BQSTART
These are not catastrophes?
BQENDIf it happens to you then it likely is a catastrophe.
BQSTART
OK Mr Clever, why are people so worried about AGW? We hear and read a lot about extreme weather events, water scarcity, acidifying oceans, 
BQEND"Catastrophe" is a value judgement.
We are concerned that rising temperatures will have a steadily increasing impact on our economic growth and capacity to spread wealth to the peoples of the world. That some will be devastatingly negatively affected. On the balance of risks the working assummptions are that either 1.5C or 2C warming is something we can live with economically. Above these two limits (that are debated) the assumption is negative impacts increase exponentially.

http://www.ipcc.ch/pdf/assessment-report/ar5/wg2/ar5_wgII_spm_en.pdf
BQSTART
ncreasing magnitudes of warming increase the likelihood of severe, pervasive, and irreversible impacts. S ome risks of climate change are considerable at 1 or 2°C above preindustrial levels (as shown in Assessment Box SPM.1). Global climate change risks are high to very high with global mean temperature increase of 4°C or more above preindustrial levels in all reasons for concern (Assessment Box SPM.1), and include severe and widespread impacts on unique and threatened systems, substantial species extinction, large risks to global and regional food security, and the combination of high temperature and humidity compromising normal human activities, including growing food or working outdoors in some areas for parts of the year ( high confidence ). The precise levels of climate change sufficient to trigger tipping points (thresholds for abrupt and irreversible change) remain uncertain, but the risk associated with crossing multiple tipping points in the earth system or in interlinked human and natural systems increases with rising temperature ( medium confidence ). 45
BQEND
Here is the World Economic Forum report on risks

http://www3.weforum.org/docs/GRR17_Report_web.pdf
Figure 3 gives an over view of the matrix of risks to the global economy.
BQSTART
his shows that ineffective management of the “global commons” – the oceans, atmosphere, and climate system – can have local as well as global consequences. For example, changing weather patterns or water crises can trigger or exacerbate geopolitical and societal risks such as domestic or regional conflict and involuntary migration, particularly in geopolitically fragile areas. Further progress was made during 2016 in addressing climate and other environmental risks, reflecting firm international resolve on the transition to a low-carbon global economy and on building resilience to climate change: – The Paris Agreement on climate change entered into force on 4
BQEND
(The quote is not the best, but I time limits and this is a rather deeply buried thread few will read).
We are not working against "catastrophe\non catastrophe" but a steady ratcheting of risks with the 2C guardrail an arbitrary goal to aim for, like a speed limit.', u'recommendation_count': u'5', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1538127918000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'16773618', u'in_reply_to': u'120933859', u'id': u'120934438', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'James Holland', u'text': u'Odd; a little while ago you were lecturing people on their lack of concern for the poor habitants of what you and the 1970's call "the third world". description: John Abraham: Do you know how an ice sheet can move? You’ll find out below.
headline: N
og_fields.og:description: John Abraham: Do you know how an ice sheet can move? You’ll find out below.
og_fields.og:title: New research shows the world’s ice is doing something not seen before | John Abraham
text:
In this warming world, some parts of the planet are warming much faster than others.  The warming is causing large ice bodies to start to melt and move rapidly, in some cases sliding into the ocean.  
This movement is the topic of a very new scientific study that was just published in the journal Earth and Planetary Science Letters.  The Arctic is warming much faster than other parts of the planet and the ice there is showing the signs of rapid warming.  This fact has serious consequences. First, melting ice can cause sea levels to rise and inundate coastal areas – it also makes storms like hurricanes and typhoons more destructive.  Melting ice also causes a feedback loop, which can cause more future warming and then more ice loss.
It should be noted that there are different types of ice.  Some ice floats on water and is called sea ice.  When it melts, the ocean water level hardly budges because the ice is already in the sea displacing liquid water.  But, sea ice is really important for this feedback loop I mentioned above. 
Other ice is on land and may be a large ice sheet or a smaller glacier.  These ice bodies sit atop the land and “rest” there.  In some cases, they extend out off the land and into the ocean where they partly float on liquid water.  When this land ice melts, the liquid flows into the oceans and can cause significant ocean level rising.
So, the importance of ice depends on what type it is, where it is located, and how fast it is melting. And this brings us to the new paper.
The researchers looked at a type of high latitude glacier in their study.  These glaciers hold enough water to cause about 1 foot (about a third of a meter) in sea level rise. Typically, they exist in cold and dry areas, where snowfall is limited.  
How do glaciers move?  Well really by either sliding over the underlying bedrock or surface that they sit on, or by deforming and stretching under their weight. The colder glaciers tend to move by the deforming and stretching process.  Glaciers that have wetter and more temperate regions involve more sliding.  But regardless of how they move, these glaciers, particularly the glaciers that have both cold and temperate parts, experience surges in their motion.  These surges are short duration times where the glacier moves a lot.  During a surge, ice is redistributed from one part of the glacier to another region.
The authors in this study observed such a glacier surge.  It happened at an outlet glacier that is mainly of the “cold” type in Russia.  At the Vavilov Ice Cap on October Revolution Island, the authors find it “is undergoing extraordinary acceleration and thinning but displays no previous evidence of surging.”  The authors write,
the 300-600 meter thick 1820 square kilometer Vavilov Ice Cap is frozen to its bed over the majority of its area, apart from a region along its western margin where basal sliding is potentially important for faster flow. 
In 2010 the ice in the region began to accelerate and the next year, crevasses were observed that matched the patterns of ice acceleration. The researchers were able to watch this surge in ice motion in real-time using satellite images. They could track the motion and show the incredible speed of flow. 
What caused the rapid motion? This is an important question because if the motion is caused by human warming, we can expect the behavior to be repeated elsewhere as temperatures rise.  Importantly both air and ocean-water temperatures could be a factor.  One potential cause is surface meltwater.  The top of the ice can melt, and liquid water then can flow downwards, into the ice through cracks and holes.  This flowing water can precondition the ice for rapid motion. 
This fact may be a contributing cause to the motion.  Basically, the melted water lubricated the ice/ground interface causing more sliding and more friction.  The friction caused some of the bottom ice to melt and released more liquid water, and a cycle had begun.
The researchers also took measurements of elevation to better understand areas where ice was becoming thicker or thinner.  In addition, they studied the forces that exist within the ice itself to help elucidate the cause of the increased speed. Obviously, this is an evolving area of study and all of the questions have not yet been answered.  However, I was impressed when I read that even though these types of surges are becoming more common, what the researchers observed in Russia was still unique.  They describe the rate of ice loss at Vavilov as “extreme.” The authors also point out, 
It is startling that the Vavilov Ice Cap, until recently, an apparently stable ice cap with an almost entirely frozen bed that is almost entirely above sea level, is able to rapidly discharge such a large proportion of its ice in the ocean over such a short period.
So, to answer the question, how fast is it moving?  In 2015, it reached speeds of up to 82 feet in a single day. It currently is sliding 15–35 feet a day. For comparison, that is much faster than the average 2 inches per day we would see with no surge events.
The takeaway message is that once we thought these large bodies of ice responded slowly to changing conditions.  But this research shows us differently.  It shows that ice sheet can move quickly and once we pass a threshold, they may be hard to stop.  This finding makes it more crucial for us to slow down global warming before it’s too late.

description: Environmentalists accuse government of using withdrawal of EU controls to weaken regulation
headline: l
og_fields.og:description: Environmentalists accuse government of using withdrawal of EU controls to weaken regulation
og_fields.og:title: UK’s green watchdog will be powerless over climate change post-Brexit
text:
Ministers are “deliberately weakening” the green watchdog that will hold the government to account after Britain leaves the EU, according to Labour’s shadow Brexit minister.
Theresa May pledged last January to create a “world-leading, independent, statutory body” to ensure ministers stick to their commitments – replacing the power of the European commission to take governments to the European court of justice (ECJ) for not fulfilling their obligations.
Yet the UK watchdog will not have any powers relating to climate change, an issue of heightened public concern since the summer heatwave that has seen wildfires in the north of England and outbreaks of tropical diseases in parts of Europe.
Matthew Pennycook, Labour’s Brexit spokesman, said: “Our EU membership has been key to delivering and enforcing UK emission reductions. In choosing to exclude climate change from the remit of their environmental watchdog, ministers are deliberately weakening the tools we have to hold them to account. The Brexit process cannot be used as a cover to water down the UK’s leadership on climate change.”
The public deserves to have a watchdog with teeth that can enforce climate policy and ensure our pledges become reality
Greener UK, which represents 13 of the UK’s biggest environmental organisations including Friends of the Earth, Greenpeace, the RSPB and the National Trust , said it is very concerned about the omission of climate policy from the watchdog’s remit. About 55% of the UK’s planned carbon reductions are tied to regulations derived from the EU and would have been enforced by the European commission.
The watchdog should cover issues such as protecting harbour porpoises, ensuring that water quality and air quality remain high, and protecting wildlife habitats – issues that the European commission has taken action against the UK government.
Environmentalists believe the ECJ has been effective in getting Whitehall to live up to its pledges. According to research by the Institute for Government, between 2003 and 2016 the commission started 753 actions against the British government, of which about 120 related to the environment. Yet ministers were quick to settle matters before they reached the ECJ, which only passed judgments on 63 cases. However, 29 of those cases related to the environment, indicating that ministers would often not take action unless forced to do so.
In announcing its plans for the watchdog, the government argued that climate change was already covered by the Climate Change Act 2008, which created the committee on climate change and international treaties. But the CCC, which said recently that the UK would miss its 2025 and 2030 carbon reduction targets, only has powers to advise and report.
Its chairman, Lord Deben, told the environment secretary Michael Gove that excluding climate policy from the watchdog’s remit would be “artificial and potentially create problems”. But Gove is not responsible for government policy on climate change. The issue has now been passed over to the Department for Business, Energy and Industrial Strategy (BEIS).
Shane Tomlinson, director at E3G, part of Greener UK, said: “The government says it wants to be a leader in tackling climate change. However, leadership is not just about the promises you make, but being accountable for delivering on them.
“The UK public deserves to have a watchdog with teeth that can enforce climate policy and ensure that our pledges become reality.”
A spokesman for the BEIS said the government was committed to meeting its climate change targets.

description: French president accused of doing too little, as he appoints new environment minister
headline: l
og_fields.og:description: French president accused of doing too little, as he appoints new environment minister
og_fields.og:title: Emmanuel Macron under attack over climate change
text:
French environment campaigners have warned Emmanuel Macron is doing too little to combat climate change and must radically rethink his environment policy if he is to honour his promise to “make this planet great again”.
Renewed criticism of the centrist French president’s approach to green issues came as Macron replaced his former environment minister, the TV personality Nicolas Hulot, who quit last week saying the government was in thrall to powerful lobby groups and taking only “mini-steps” that were insufficient to deal with climate change.
Macron replaced Hulot with the parliament speaker, François de Rugy, a former Green party figure who jumped ship to Macron’s party, La République En Marche, last year. 
De Rugy was active in environmental politics for 25 years before opposing what he called a shift further left by the French Green party. He is described as a pragmatist and reformist who is loyal to Macron.
But environmental groups immediately questioned whether De Rugy would be able to have an effect on the government’s approach to climate change, saying Macron must better defend biodiversity and address environmental threats. 
Macron insists he has gone further on green issues than any other French government, but Jean-François Julliard, the director general of Greenpeace France, said it was clear “the environment is not a priority for Emmanuel Macron and [the prime minister] Édouard Philippe who just use it as window dressing without any real will to engage on environmental transition”. He said he feared De Rugy would simply be “his master’s voice” and added: “Macron must at last take measure of the huge responsibility on his shoulders.”
Karima Delli, a Green member of the European parliament, said people wanted “a new pact for ecology”.
Pascal Canfin, the head of the World Wildlife Fund in France, who was a development minister in the last leftwing government, said a 21st-century shift was needed on clean energy “but the state is still set up as if it’s the 20th – or even 19th – century”.
 Although Macron did not make environmental issues a major part of his election manifesto last year, he later attempted to push them to the forefront as a symbol of progressive politics and to counter Donald Trump’s decision to take the US out of the Paris climate accord. Addressing the US Congress in April, Macron told American lawmakers: “There is no Planet B.”
The first challenge for De Rugy will be addressing future energy plans for France, a country overwhelmingly dependent on nuclear energy. The government announced in November that France’s long-held goal of bringing its reliance on nuclear energy down to 50% by 2025 was not feasible and was likely to take a decade longer.
Taking office, De Rugy said there was an “urgent” need to act on the environment. “I’m here to take action,” he said.
In recent weeks, Macron’s approval ratings have dropped to the lowest since he came to power, as he faces slower economic growth, and struggles to shake off the label “president of the rich”. Over the summer, he faced the first major political scandal of his presidency when a senior security aide was filmed violently assaulting a young man and woman at the edge of a Paris demonstration.
Also, it was reported on Tuesday that the surprise resignation of the popular sports minister and Olympic medallist, Laura Flessel, was linked to her tax situation. The French investigative website Mediapart reported that tax investigators had recently notified France’s tax infraction commission over suspicions she had under-reported her earnings.

article_tags: [Climate change, Pacific Islands Forum, Australia news, Environment, World news, South Pacific, Scott Morrison, Palau, Samoa]
description: Leaders of Pacific Forum Island countries call on United States to return to Paris agreement on climate change
headline: l
og_fields.og:description: Leaders of Pacific Forum Island countries call on United States to return to Paris agreement on climate change
og_fields.og:title: Australia signs declaration saying climate change 'single greatest threat' to Pacific
text:
Climate change is the single greatest security threat to the Pacific, and all countries must meet their commitments under the Paris climate agreement, the 18 countries of the Pacific Islands Forum said on Wednesday.
The first assertion of the strongly worded Boe Declaration says all Pacific nations, including Australia, “reaffirm that climate change remains the single greatest threat to the livelihoods, security and wellbeing of the peoples of the Pacific, and our commitment to progress the implementation of the Paris agreement.
“Leaders reaffirmed the importance of immediate urgent action to combat climate change and … called on countries, particularly large emitters, to fully implement their … mitigation targets, including through the development and transfer of renewable energy, in line with committed timeframes.”
Leaders of the Forum Islands countries also called for the US to return to the Paris agreement and the commitments it made under President Barack Obama.
The Boe Declaration said the security challenges being faced by Pacific nations were broader and more complex than in previous generations. The forum committed its members to addressing humanitarian assistance, environmental and resource security, transnational crime and cybersecurity.
Australia will work with regional security agencies to establish a Pacific Fusion Centre to better share intelligence and target threats including illegal fishing, drug trafficking and other cross-border crimes.
But the forthright declaration on climate is awkward politically for Australia, with its new prime minister, Scott Morrison, apparently at odds with his own government’s Energy Security Board over whether Australia will meet its Paris targets of a 26% reduction in emissions from 2005 levels.
The government does not have any emissions reductions policies in place to achieve the target.
Morrison told a radio program on Wednesday that “the business-as-usual model gets us there [meeting the Paris targets] in a canter”.
But the Energy Security Board said business as usual – and a failure to implement the now-discarded national energy guarantee – would mean the electricity sector would “fall short of the emissions reduction target of 26% below 2005 levels”.
The Australian government’s apparent ambivalence towards a low-emissions climate policy has disquieted its Pacific neighbours.
As a region, the Pacific has produced the least carbon of any areaon Earth but its citizens have felt the impacts of climate change first, and most acutely, through rising seas, increased salinity, and more frequent and severe natural disasters.
Low-lying island Pacific countries including Kiribati are forecast to be among the first on the plant to disappear underwater if rising sea levels are not arrested.
Xavier Matsutaro, the national climate change coordinator for Palau, a small nation in the north-west Pacific, told the Guardian Australia’s relationship with the Pacific was “dysfunctional”, adding that Australia was also responsible for diluting the strength of previous regional declarations on climate change.
“Australia is a bit of an anomaly, because on the floor [of climate summits] they’re basically sometimes as far right as Trump in some of their views on climate change, at one point they even denied that it existed … But then on a regional basis they’ve actually given a lot of support to our region,” Matsutaro said.
“Sometimes the way I think about it ... it’s like you’re in a relationship and you get abused by your spouse but at the same time they feed you and clothe you and things like that,” he said. “You could say it’s a bit of a dysfunctional relationship.”
In a blistering speech in Sydney last month, Samoa’s prime minister, Tuilaepa Sailele, called climate change an “existential threat ... for all our Pacific family” and said any world leader who denied climate change’s existence was “utterly stupid”.

article_tags: [Climate change scepticism, Climate change, BBC, Climate change, Environment, Media]
description: Briefing sent to editorial staff on global warming says ‘you do not need a denier to balance the debate’
headline: l
og_fields.og:description: Briefing sent to editorial staff on global warming says ‘you do not need a denier to balance the debate’
og_fields.og:title: BBC admits ‘we get climate change coverage wrong too often’
text:
The BBC has accepted it gets coverage of climate change “wrong too often” and told staff: “You do not need a ‘denier’ to balance the debate.”
In a briefing note sent to all staff warning them to be aware of false balance, the corporation has offered a training course on how to report on global warming. The move follows a series of apologies and censures for failing to challenge climate sceptics during interviews, including Nigel Lawson.
The briefing note, obtained by the website Carbon Brief, was sent on Thursday by Fran Unsworth, the BBC’s director of news and current affairs. It includes a statement of BBC editorial policy that begins: “Climate change has been a difficult subject for the BBC, and we get coverage of it wrong too often.”
It then states: “Manmade climate change exists: If the science proves it we should report it.” In the section warning on false balance it says: “To achieve impartiality, you do not need to include outright deniers of climate change in BBC coverage, in the same way you would not have someone denying that Manchester United won 2-0 last Saturday. The referee has spoken.”
The Guardian revealed in October that the BBC had apologised for an interview with Lord Lawson on the Radio 4 Today programme after admitting it had breached its own editorial guidelines for allowing him to claim that global temperatures have not risen in the past decade. The regulator Ofcom subsequently ruled the BBC had breached broadcasting rules.
The Today programme was also censured by the BBC complaints unit for an interview with Lawson in February 2014 and has been criticised for failing to implement fully the findings of the BBC Trust’s 2011 review into the “accuracy of the BBC’s coverage of science”.
The four-page briefing note sent by Unsworth starts with a blunt statement on the science: “Climate change IS happening.” It also covers the implications of global warming: “There is a general consensus that it could be devastating in many different ways.” It ends with “common misconceptions” used to deny manmade warming, including that “not all scientists think manmade climate change is real” and “climate change has happened before”.
The briefing note does not completely rule out including climate sceptics in BBC coverage: “There are occasions where contrarians and sceptics should be included. These may include, for instance, debating the speed and intensity of what will happen in the future, or what policies government should adopt.”
But it adds: “Journalists need to be aware of the guest’s viewpoint and how to challenge it effectively. As with all topics, we must make clear to the audience which organisation the speaker represents, potentially how that group is funded and whether they are speaking with authority from a scientific perspective.” Lawson’s Global Warming Policy Foundation does not disclose its source of funding.
Richard Black, director of the Energy and Climate Intelligence Unit thinktank and a former BBC environment correspondent, said: “The creation of this course is welcome news. The BBC was wrong in my view to scrap the science seminars that it set up in 2011 – very few producers and presenters have a science background.
“The course will be criticised by some – words like ‘stifling the debate’ – but those voices are decreasingly important in the country. I think the real takeaway from this is that the BBC has decided it no longer cares about evidence-free allegations of ‘bias’. It’s to be commended for putting its mojo on display.”
Prof Ed Hawkins, a climate scientist at the University of Reading, said: “This set of BBC guidelines is long overdue. There have been too many occasions when the BBC’s audience has been misled over the realities of climate change.”
Hawkins analysed the briefing note for Carbon Brief saying: “The ‘editorial policy’ could be more explicit about what would constitute false balance in its coverage. In the past, too many inaccurate statements made about climate science have not been effectively challenged by the interviewer.”
In August, 57 prominent environmentalists, including Jonathon Porritt and Caroline Lucas, wrote to the Guardian declaring: “We will no longer debate those who deny that human-caused climate change is real. There are plenty of vital debates to be had around climate chaos and what to do about it; this is simply no longer one of them. We urge broadcasters to move on, as we are doing.”
The BBC declined to offer further comment.

description: Energy company SSE claims thousands of new points are in bureaucratic limbo
headline: i
og_fields.og:description: Energy company SSE claims thousands of new points are in bureaucratic limbo
og_fields.og:title: London councils accused of holding up rollout of electric car charging points
text:
Britain has thousands fewer electric car charging points than required because councils are frustrating their rollout, according to one of the country’s biggest energy companies.
Big six energy firm SSE said that when it started work three years ago, it had hoped to install 6,000 charging points in London by now, but had fitted just 762 because of delays by local authorities.
The company is the contractor putting in the chargers for the Source London network, run by French firm Bolloré.
Sadiq Khan, the mayor of London, has backed electric vehicle infrastructure to help clean up the capital’s dirty air, but his rhetoric has reportedly not filtered down to the local level.
Slow decision-making and bureaucracy in councils, coupled with different approaches to charge points across the capital’s boroughs, are understood to have hamstrung the rollout.
Kevin Welstead, the sector director for electric vehicles at SSE Enterprise, said: “Progress has not been rapid. The issue is that we have to effectively negotiate with each of the 33 individual London boroughs so we can install charge points alongside their parking bays and some are more progressive on the electric vehicle agenda than others.”
The Guardian understands that 130 charging points are in limbo in Southwark, a borough which is otherwise seen as good on electric cars. While the points were given planning approval in 2016, permission has not been given by highways management, meaning they cannot be installed. Planning permission expires next year.
Welstead said ministers and Khan had rightly supported electric vehicles, but added: “Our experience as an infrastructure provider on the ground is that this message has not seeped all the way through.”
One possible reason for holdups could be the financial problems that austerity has imposed. Cuts to central government grants have led local authorities to shed staff, including those on transport teams, and remaining staff are understood to be stretched to capacity.
We’d like your help to find out more about current or future cuts to UK council services. If you’re aware of any where you live, please get in touch.
You can share your knowledge and possible news tips by filling in this encrypted form – anonymously if you wish. One of our journalists may be in touch and we will consider some of your responses in our reporting. You can read terms of service here.
Another explanation could be that some boroughs are not seeing much demand from constituents, so are not prioritising approvals. There has also reportedly been a growth in very localised opposition, including in conservation areas.
However, there are hotspots of demand for charging points, including Camden, Islington, Kensington & Chelsea, Hammersmith & Fulham and Southwark.
The mayor of London launched an electric vehicle infrastructure taskforce in May, focused on “rapid chargers”, not the slower chargers that comprise most of the Source London network. There are nearly 4,000 charging points in London, according to Zap Map.
London Councils, which represents the city’s 33 boroughs, denied holding back the switch to electric cars.
Councillor Julian Bell, who chairs the group’s transport and environment committee, said: “London boroughs are committed to supporting environmentally friendly transport and are leading the way in delivering an effective network of electric vehicle charging points across the capital.”
He added that boroughs also had “a duty to consider the needs of pedestrians and other road users and to make sure these services are delivered to high standards”.
Southwark council did not deny that 130 chargers were in limbo, but said it had 100-150 lamp-post electric car charging points planned for the next 12 months.

I suggest you try the experiment for yourself, and then come back and tell us about it. Or if you're smart, you'd take the word of Iowa State Universty:
How dangerous is it to operate an engine in a closed building? So dangerous that it must NEVER be done, even for a short time. The extremely high concentrations of carbon monoxide produced by an engine can raise CO concentrations in a closed building so quickly that a person may collapse before they even realize there is a problem. Carbon monoxide reduces the amount of oxygen to the brain, causing CO intoxication, and lack of reasoning. Studies by the Centers for Disease Control found that CO concentrations reach the Immediately Dangerous to Life and Health (IDLH) concentration of 1,200 parts per million (ppm) in only 7 minutes when a small 5 horsepower gasoline engine is run in a 10,000 cubic foot room.

I feel the bbc have made it far less likely for anyone to be able to voice all these related questions', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1536593324000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u'it means that in most peoples minds listening to the bbc fossil fuels are bad and yet there might just be an argument to say that some global warming is a small price to lift millions out of poverty', u'effect': u'do you not think its all tied to the issue'}], u'author_id': u'15071406', u'in_reply_to': u'120279726', u'id': u'120280166', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'JulesBywaterLees', u'text': u'I treat as a bit of brain exercise- and practise in keeping replies concise and clear', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1536593233000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'4738374', u'in_reply_to': u'120279506', u'id': u'120280104', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'David Jones', u'text': u'Many contrarian views actually disballance the debate since their presence shifts the debate toward already settled issues. Removing their clearly false views from the media actually balances out the conversation and allows everyone to focus on the things that do need to be discussed such as how to implement actions and the specifics of what we can expect due to the changes our emissions are causing. Generally, if you want to keep such views represented, they should at the very least be challenged immediately by the media hosts.
In terms of politics, especially unnecessary to the conversation are the think tanks and political “philanthropic” organizations derived from or associated with the US and other fossil fuel industry elements which are also driving political developments abroad. 
Free speech is actually being used in nefarious and cynically ironic ways to allow for such think tanks to spread misinformation and confuse the public unimpeded. 
This is how cynical the US fossil fuel industry and their allies truly are in their highest ranks, they don’t believe in unity (Citizens United has divided the US), democracy (they have manipulated elections around the world and at home) or the equal voting rights of individuals (leveraging the US electoral collage to subvert the democratic majority vote) and they are using pillars of democracy and freedom to manipulate and deceive the public.
For instance, one of the recent actions taken by the current US administration was to obscure funding to these “philanthropic” organizations and think tanks based on a false application of the idea of free speech, the result of which is to allow such organizations that are aggressively politically active both at home and abroad to act without accountability. This opens up a new level of corruption.
It is important to know what we are dealing with, if freedom of speech is affected in a negative way it is as a result of the cynical and destructive actions I pointed out above but I don’t think that removing such bad actors is actually working against free speech. 
A balanced conversation is important but spreading falsehoods and misinformation is not something that adds balance, it has the opposite effect.', u'recommendation_count': u'3', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1536593193000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u'the changes our emissions are causing', u'effect': u'what we can expect'}, {u'cause': u'our emissions', u'effect': None}], u'author_id': u'17095222', u'in_reply_to': u'120278016', u'id': u'120280085', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'PercyThrills', u'text': u'“An hypothesis that is unfalsifiable is not an hypothesis.”

BQEND
Consensus comes from the evidence, not the other way around. Wegener did get a very hard time in the early years but from first publication of a thoroughly speculative idea to widespread acceptance - « consensus » - took no more than 50 years. During that time his ideas were refined (coherence), many other lines of evidence were found (consilience) and as a result the overall theory became widely accepted (consensus). This is a very typical pathway: hard work and gathering information improve our understanding of the world around us. Not people saying « it must a conspiracy ! »
Scientific results that have the potential to change or enhance our understanding would always be reported, but Nigel Lawson would and should not be considered a suitable person to comment on it. description: The BBC seems to be moving away from feeling obliged to give equal weight to the views of the likes of Lord Lawson, says Richard Black, director of the Energy and Climate Intelligence Unit
og_fields.og:description: The BBC seems to be moving away from feeling obliged to give equal weight to the views of the likes of Lord Lawson, says Richard Black, director of the Energy and Climate Intelligence Unit
og_fields.og:title: No more BBC platform for climate change deniers? It’d be about time | Richard Black
text:
From time to time the BBC gets itself into an awful mess over climate change. Unnecessarily so, given that it has visited and revisited principles of good coverage, repeatedly arriving at more or less the same conclusions.
Back in 2007, a report for the BBC Trust, then the corporation’s regulator, concluded that the old bipolar world of “the climate change debate” had gone. The working model had to change, as the title put it, From Seesaw to Wagon Wheel : “the weight of evidence no longer justifies equal space being given to the opponents of the consensus. But these dissenters (or even sceptics) will still be heard, as they should.” Four years later, the Trust’s review of accuracy and impartiality in science coverage , commissioned from geneticist Professor Steve Jones, reached very similar conclusions.
Both reports were accepted by BBC managers. Both contain much that is common sense. And then there are the editorial guidelines, which are very clear that the guiding principle is “due impartiality”, rather than equal weight.
So how have we reached a situation in which the BBC has to apologise  for not challenging incorrect statements made by Lord Lawson on the Today programme, where an entire Radio 4 feature, What’s the Point of the Met Office?, turns into a polemic about “dodgy” climate science, and where Radio Cambridgeshire finds it appropriate to stage a traditional seesaw-style debate between “warmist” and “sceptic”?
One answer is that the BBC has failed to promulgate its “big thinking” on editorial matters to producers and presenters, very few of whom have a science background. After the Jones Review it set up seminars on science coverage; but it failed to make them mandatory, and scrapped them after a year. Staff come and staff go; it seems extremely unlikely that Sarah Sands, editor of Today, had read either the Jones Review or From Seesaw to Wagon Wheel when she decided to call Nigel Lawson for “that” interview.
I recently argued for the seminars’ reinstatement and for making them mandatory. Not that I’m claiming credit, but as the CarbonBrief website has reported, the BBC has now done something similar – setting up a new one-hour course on reporting climate change “… covering the latest science, policy, research, and misconceptions to challenge, giving you confidence to cover the topic accurately and knowledgeably”.
The basic briefing document for the course is short, but it’s a good start. “Climate change is happening”; there is a range of possible temperature rises for any given level of carbon emissions; one cold winter does not challenge the overall picture; and so on. Unchallengeable, really.
If the courses are implemented well, they should improve matters still further. I say “still further” because the lapses to which I referred earlier are conspicuous by their rarity. There’s been a lot of climate change coverage this summer, and the vast majority that I’ve seen has been exemplary. But if this initiative can, for example, make sure that Today presenters know that individual extreme weather events are now routinely being linked to climate change, as Nick Robinson appeared not to know when talking about the heatwave recently, that will be a step forward.
Climate science, though, is just part of the picture. The corporation’s coverage of energy could do with an infusion of new thinking on issues linked to climate change. Mercifully the stream of claims that “the lights will go out” as Britain adopts more and more renewable energy appears to have stopped. But which of the BBC’s correspondents knows that energy bills have gone down over the past decade? Not those who last year covered the government-commissioned Helm Review of energy prices, which led to Radio 4 claiming that “bills have doubled over the past decade”. Where is coverage, also, of the existential risk posed to oil companies – and therefore our pension funds – by the tumbling prices of renewable energy and electric cars? This is now standard fare for the FT, Economist, Telegraph, Reuters, Bloomberg … But the BBC has yet to catch on that a transformation of the entire global energy system is a big story.
The other major factor behind the BBC’s occasional troubles on climate change is lobbying. The newspaper commentariat is amply stocked with columnists who routinely lambast the corporation for bias; and the weight of rhetoric has had an impact.
This, I think, is the real takeaway from the CarbonBrief news: the BBC has decided that it no longer cares about groundless criticism. I assume that the first fulmination against this new course will be in print this weekend or early next week, doubtless full of words such as “indoctrination”. The BBC will be accused of “stifling debate”, even though the course material is clear that it is not. Probably the identity of the “shadowy” figures behind this initiative will be sought.
The reality is, though, that climate and energy contrarians are exerting less and less influence on media or politics. As the BBC’s online briefing notes, the government is now taking advice on whether to set a net-zero emissions target in law, not debating whether climate change matters. If BBC bosses have decided that from now on they are going to free output from the occasional grip of the UK’s climate contrarian elite and stand up for evidence – good on them.
• Richard Black is director of the Energy and Climate Intelligence Unit, and a former BBC science and environment correspondent

Please ignore that para.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1536710497000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u'over supply', u'effect': u'over supply'}, {u'cause': None, u'effect': u'shortages'}], u'author_id': u'13835441', u'in_reply_to': u'120337273', u'id': u'120337377', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Pushers11', u'text': u'Thanks for your points. Interesting take.
However, how can we talk about pollution and not point a very, very critical finger at governments? After all, governments the world over are the biggest polluters, bar none. The US military machine for example burns through as much oil in a day as a country the size of Greece. And that is just one (albeit large) arm of one government. For governments to try to tell the average Joe they need to cut back on things whilst they carry on polluting in the way they do is hypocritical in the extreme.
Why shouldn't investors get a return on their money in the bank? The money is not doing "nothing". The more reserves a bank has, the more they can lend out to productive businesses and start-ups. If they are lending, they are earning interest. And in turn, should give savers some of the interest - that is the way it has historically worked. The reason the BoE should not be holding the base rate at zero is because the BoE should not be price fixing anything - let alone something as important as the interest rate. It shouldn't be up to a bunch of central planners to decide. Price fixing is a terrible, terrible idea. We don't want government price fixing the price of bread (for example). We have all seen the bread lines in Soviet Russia when their government tried. The BoE shouldn't be let anywhere near the interest rate. The market should decide what it is, just like it decides most prices in our economy. When you price fix something too low, you get an over supply and when you price fix something too high, you get shortages. The price of money has been set extremely low and lo and behold, we have vast amounts of credit that is only adding to inflation and eating away at the value of our money. The very fact that we have a central bank doing just that means we fundamentally do not have anything close to a free market economy.
Sure, private ownership of the land could solve air pollution. If you have unclean air coming over your property and you can trace it back to its source, you could easily sue the other party.
Private property is completely inherent to free markets. You cannot have a market system without them. Be that property of goods, ideas, art, music, etc or land itself. So it is completely in-line with free markets. I personally think the problem of housing is not a problem of ownership of the land but rather one, again, of government interference in the market of housing and land. It takes so long (in most cases) to get approval for buildings and/or land "re-zoning" that most take years to go through. And when they do it becomes more cost efficient for the developer to build housing that appeals to a higher end of the market - so they can more quickly recoup the costs they had in going through the approval process - that a) not enough cheaper housing gets built and b) not enough housing full-stop gets built. So supply cannot keep up with demand. Prices go up (and inflation driven by the central bank helps drives those prices up as well. As does holding an interest rate artificially low so that investors have to look to investments other than saving to actually get a return, driving many into housing - say hello bubble like we had in the run up to 08)
I am not saying there is no role for government in a market. You need a referee so to speak. But they should be there to keep the market "free". And what does the free in free market refer to? It means free from force and compulsion. It has to be voluntary transactions. So that means the government needs to stop fraud, extortion, blackmail, theft, murder, etc - stopping the violations of other individuals rights. But other than that, it should not have a role. Anything more is just favouring one side over the other and creating an un-level playing field. Which is why of course most of the big companies LOVE regulation because they have the money to lobby and get a say in the wording and framing of the laws, so they benefit at the expense of the little guy competition. They are the ones also that can pay for the teams of lawyers needed just to keep up with all compliance.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1536710124000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u'the boe should not be price fixing anything let', u'effect': u'the reason the boe should not be holding the base rate at zero is'}, {u'cause': u'they have the money to lobby and get a say in the wording and framing of the laws', u'effect': u'why of course most of the big companies love regulation'}], u'author_id': u'13835441', u'in_reply_to': u'120330811', u'id': u'120337273', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Pushk1n', u'text': u'To be fair, Telecoms was a success, British Airways, even BP though sold at a loss were also success's to an extent though we could have gone Norway and let the benefits return to a wealth fund which would now be useful.
However Water has been a significant failure in the case of Thames Water all the money went to an Australian wealth extraction fund.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1536701945000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'1611394', u'in_reply_to': u'120302985', u'id': u'120334352', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'AbbyLox', u'text': u'I feel the need to match the length of your response, so here goes...
I think it would be challenging to argue that pollution (as an example negative externality) has been tackled better by the private sector alone than when government regulation is involved. It’s a clear example of a market failure I think.
If savers want a return they should invest in productive endeavours. I don’t see any reason that they should expect interest for doing nothing. In fact I see no reason for the BOE base rate to be anything other than zero. Why should the government pay interest on bank reserves?
Fait money makes more sense than a commodity backed currency which can starve the economy of the money it needs to operate efficiently. This leads to lost production and recessions. Hardly a desirable situation surely?
While private ownership of all land is one solution to a Tragedy of the Commons type problem it certainly doesn’t lead to an efficient economy. There is also the problem of air pollution which wouldn’t be solved by this. 
Also, it’s seems strange for you to suggest this given your (presumed) preference for free markets. Private ownership of land is a great example of a non-free market. In fact, the housing problems in this country are potentially caused by the non-free nature of the land market. If government regulation was used to resolve this (i.e. a land value tax) the resulting distribution of land would be more economically efficient which would boost the economy.
Of course, just because government regulation can improve markets doesn’t mean all regulation does this. Clearly there are many examples of bad laws. However, in a market based economy I believe one of the key roles for government is to use regulation to remove externalities where possible and make markets free where necessary. Profit means research and development .. and it is R&D that will make a better world .. not ethical hand wringing.', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1536680781000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'14905892', u'id': u'120322327', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Hellequin123', u'text': u'Nothing to do with this article but just to say, I had a look at flat earthers on youtube last night. Oh dear is all I can say. There's even some doctors (not sure what they're doctors of, of course) agreeing with it all. So I gather, they actually think it's like a snow globe. Good for chuckle though, if somewhat worrying. Anyway, I did look.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1536680457000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'3659646', u'in_reply_to': u'120319031', u'id': u'120322146', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Pushers11', u'text': u'Good question. Yes of course negative externalities exist. But they always will, with or without government intervention. And indeed, in most cases government intervention only makes things worse.
Take one small (but critical) example. Many say the way the current economy is going is focused too much on consumerism and using up resources too quickly. However, why is that? Why do so few these days look to the long term and save? Why spend so much right now? Well, the government via the central bank controls the interest rate and what is used as the official money supply.
If savers know they cannot get any return on their money by leaving it in a bank it tends to tip the scale towards spending. That coupled with the fact that because we have fiat based currency, rather than sound money (i.e. a money that is backed by some commodity), that the central bank deliberately aims to inflate over time which lowers its purchasing power in the long run. So not only do savers not earn any interest, leaving it in the bank actually costs them money over time due to the erosion of value. In those circumstances it makes complete, rational sense to spend in the here and now when you money has some value than save for the longer term. These circumstances are both the product of government intervention. If the interest rate was market set it would be a lot higher than it is now and would encourage saving. As would the market decide what we accept as money, meaning less (if any) inflation, again encouraging saving and investing, rather than spending today.
Or take pollution directly. Almost any new energy technology will produce pollution. And it takes time for the technology to become cleaner. But if we had the level of regulation back in the 1800s that we have today, the industrial revolution would never have happened in the first place and we would be stuck living like back then, with all their problems and poverty. However, the market, given time, comes up with the solutions to the pollution because consumers demand it.

Within a couple hundred years, humans will be living in a climate the Earth hasn’t seen since the Pliocene, three million years ago, when oceans were seventy-five feet higher than they are now. Once the methane hydrates under the oceans and permafrost begin to melt, we may soon find ourselves living in a hothouse climate closer to that of the Paleocene-Eocene Thermal Maximum, approximately fifty-six million years ago, when the planet was ice free and tropical at the poles. We face the imminent collapse of the agricultural, shipping, and energy networks upon which the global economy depends, a large-scale die-off in the biosphere that’s already well underway, and our own possible extinction as a species.What’s even more shocking is that it’s probably already too late to stop it, even if the world’s political and economic elites were willing and able to radically transform our global fossil-fueled economy, which they’re not. Scientists and environmental organizations have been working to alert politicians to the problem of global warming and to decrease carbon emissions for more than three decades, and emissions have only “increased. According to the World Bank, 2.7 degrees Fahrenheit of warming is now inevitable no matter what, even if we stopped emitting carbon dioxide worldwide today.”Excerpt From: Roy Scranton. “We're Doomed. Now What?.”', u'recommendation_count': u'2', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1536659376000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'14776906', u'id': u'120305355', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'OneNation2', u'text': u'But we knew in the 1980s that under the then new (Neo)conservative financial arrangements that pensions would become unpayable once the Ponzi like schemes arrived at their inevitable destinations.

"Profit was the answer to another century’s problems"
BQEND
Profit is still the answer. At its core profit is just a signal that tells a business it is doing the right things, just as losses are a signal that a business is doing the wrong things. The only way to make profit is by giving consumers what they want at a price they are willing to pay. If you cannot do that, you do not make profit but rather losses.
The way I see it, we have two problems that stop the profit and loss signals working the way they should. First up we do not have anything resembling free markets. We have very centralised markets where governments and central banks tell industry (some more: like finance or healthcare, and some less: like technology - interesting isn't it that the more regulated the industry, the more it struggles) what to do and what they can offer and how they can offer it. They set what the interest rate is (and price fixing has been shown time and time again to be bad idea). Its pretty much the "fascist lite" approach to the economy - i.e. keep things ostensibly in private hands but tell them how to run their business. This stop companies operating as effectively and efficiently as they otherwise would, causing a lot more waste and more errors.
The second is tied to the first. Because of the government involvement, companies get things like bailouts which completely destroys the whole point of losses and insolvency for messing up (the banks, GM, etc should never have been bailed out in 08 but rather allowed to fail). And also things like government backed insurance schemes which bail out individuals at tax payers expense. Which also destroys our individual responsibility of evaluating the risk we are taking with certain investments. There is no risk if you know the government will give you your money back.
To fix the problem we need to get the problem out of the economy, and that problem is government / central banks. Profit is not the issue.', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1536658780000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u'they', u'effect': u'a lot more waste and more errors'}], u'author_id': u'13835441', u'id': u'120304943', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'DuneMessiah', u'text': u'It was the state that bailed out the banks. Without it, the free market would have collapsed.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1536658713000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'11566098', u'in_reply_to': u'120298484', u'id': u'120304898', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'LifeinLIFE', u'text': u'This is a welcomed article on the need to make financial capital ecologically accountable. 
However, whilst finance capital accounting is divorced from natural capital accounting and carbon accounting, then there will be no meaningful mechanisms by which to ensure that the polluter (or the user) pays for negative environmental impacts whether that be greenhouse gas emissions including co2 and methane, deforestation, air pollution and toxic industrial waste. In other words, ecologically degenerative flows of people, capital, goods and services need to be taxed whether at source or as a value added tax.
However, this will inevitably hit low income families the hardest, therefore any talk of ecological taxes or ecological accountability will need to be accompanied by a means tested basic income in order to augment a just transition. 
During this just transition, ecological taxes can be used to finance the means tested basic income but can also be used to finance jobs and investment in a green new deal which at heart would include creating new forms of regenerative economic activity. This would include work upgrading the energy grid with community renewable energy, improving the energy efficiency of homes, redesignating disused greyspaces and turning them back into greenspaces and naturalspaces within which we can rebuild civic institutions that accommodate local education services, local wellbeing services and local community engagement. As such newly designated greenspaces can become multifunctional hubs of community activity to benefit both local people and local wildlife. Stoke on Trent could be a good demonstrator model of this type of green regeneration. 
Similarly if meat production and its associated supply chains are taxed for the degenerative activities that they are, this can encourage the release of agricultural land for reforestation and growing renewable resources such as hemp for use in localised industries to replace plastic consumption. 
However, this just transition will require ecological taxes and in particular, taxing financial capital flows that encourage degenerative economic activities with a means tested basic income.', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1536658642000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'2111826', u'id': u'120304833', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Bopstar', u'text': u'BQSTART
and no regulatory lever to mitigate this
BQEND
Well some people think that pricing carbon emissions into the market are one of the solutions.', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1536658601000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'3351985', u'id': u'120304806', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'DuneMessiah', u'text': u'The banks collapsed in 2008 because of the greedy and irresponsible behavior of the bankers. This was made possible by the deregulation started under Reagan and Thatcher in the 1980s. The banks should not have been bailed out, but nationalized, and the top bankers sacked.', u'recommendation_count': u'3', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1536658600000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u'the greedy and irresponsible behavior of the bankers', u'effect': u'the banks collapsed in 2008'}], u'author_id': u'11566098', u'in_reply_to': u'120298896', u'id': u'120304805', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Malcolm  Potter', u'text': u'“... if every saver and investor took their money out as cash the whole bloody system would crash and burn”
...which would make their hard-earned (in many cases) cash worthless.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1536658386000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'17582556', u'in_reply_to': u'120302126', u'id': u'120304642', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'DuneMessiah', u'text': u'Right wing people are incapable of learning the lessons of the crash or of climate change. To them, the former is just something that happens, and there's nothing you can do about it. The latter they just deny. Their belief in the free market is never shaken, no matter how many disasters it creates.', u'recommendation_count': u'3', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1536658339000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'11566098', u'id': u'120304601', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'gandrew', u'text': u'At last an article in the guardian that links economics with ecology. Take note, Larry Elliot.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1536658115000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'486189', u'id': u'120304457', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'GrumpyOldFool', u'text': u'One problem with seeking morality in banking is that human beings are simply animals like any others on this earth, and immorality has some evolutionary benefits which drive behaviour, even unconsciously. Greed, lying and selfishness lead to greater success in passing on genes to the offspring, and the enhanced lifestyle nurtures the attraction.
Of course, immorality in banking is encouraged by an immoral Government, like we have currently in the UK, and to focus only on banking is misguided.', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1536657990000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u'greed lying and selfishness', u'effect': u'greater success'}], u'author_id': u'17968071', u'id': u'120304386', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Pushers11', u'text': u'Thanks for that. I have long been saying that the finance sector's main problem is that it is over-regulated, not under-regulated as many claim. The paper you site just highlights that and how long it goes back. Both the 1929 crash and the 2008 crash were due to no free market in banking and instead a centralised market with both Central Bank and government regulating the private banks.', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1536657971000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u'no free market in banking and instead a centralised market with both central bank and government', u'effect': u'both the 1929 crash and the 2008 crash were'}], u'author_id': u'13835441', u'in_reply_to': u'120300854', u'id': u'120304376', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Erongi', u'text': u'Hank Polson at the Treasury said that CDOs and CDss did not need regulation back in 2003 along with Greenspan. He was in charge of GS up to 2006 during which period GS sold toxic products and was fined $5 billion in 2015 for this. Hank Polson was not an innocent to be in his position. He must have known the nature of the CDOs his company was selling.  GS made a loss because all asset prices were falling at that time. That doesnt make their behaviour correct otherwise why were they fined $5 billion? They clearly knew the nature of many CDOs and shorted them as well as AIG.', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1536657752000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u'all asset prices were falling at that time', u'effect': u'gs made a loss'}], u'author_id': u'12189246', u'in_reply_to': u'120302343', u'id': u'120304213', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Gegenschein', u'text': u'BQSTART
all financial endeavour has to be reimagined with the future of humanity as its explicit purpose. Profit was the answer to another century’s problems; if we don’t learn this from 2008, the lessons of 2028 will be far harsher.
BQEND
I think the lessons of 2028 will be harsh without reference to the ledger.
Financial endeavour to be reimagined by who? As long as there is a value to money, people will be motivated to seek out the arbitrage, to take advantage of the mechanics, to make a profit.
The excessive leverage that led to the GFC has been shifted from the books of the banks to the books of central banks and investment funds. The role of the gambler sitting at a desk in a bank has been taken by the corporate CFO, raising cheap funds to expand or to fund share buy backs (raising their equity price and earning their bonus). Next time round it will be the pension funds and life insurers that will need to be bailed out.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1536657479000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u'that', u'effect': u'the gfc'}], u'author_id': u'3696136', u'id': u'120304025', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'DavidPavett', u'text': u'Your response is interesting. That's not because you say something original but because you say what has been said millions of times before and is repeated daily, but you do it very clearly and succintly. But for all the repetition it is not a good argument.
It is true that capitalism has increased the world's productive capacity in a way unimaginable with any previous economic system. The material living standards of 100s of millions have been raised as never before. And liberal democratic political structures developed under capitalism have provided historically unparalleled opportunities for debate and argument (like the one we are engaged in here). 
But despite its undoubted dynamism (Marx described it as a revolutionary mode of production) capitalism is now suffereing from deep problems which are making it a threat to the great majority. (1) As an economic system it has always been unstable and prone the market crashes. Despite claims, over the last 100 years, that these can be overcome, these crashes are becoming ever more threatening. We are still living under the austerity regime imposed after the great crash of 2007/8. (2) The welfare systems created in the 20th century are now being eroded by cuts in public expenditure. This is not because inequality has been reduced. Inequality is increasing. (3) The rise of the finance sector is making parasitic capitalism increaingly dominant. The attraction of profitting without producing is underming the original dynamic of capitalism as SMEs are denied the finance they need. (4) Neo-liberal doctrines are demanding that market mechanisms and doctrines are introduced into every aspect of public life. And we have seen the effects of that on our railways. The police force is now so depleted that we are seeing the growth of private security for those who can afford it. (5) Capitalism is destroying the planet and threatening even its geophysical stabiliy. (6) Freedom , just two points. Inequality is the enemy of freedom. We have a highly monopolised media the ethos of which even dominats the ideology of our public broadcaster. Everone can can all say what they like but some voices will be amplfied by the media and some will not.
Capitalism is now turning on its former achievements. It has become a destructive system which is highly unstable, is increasing inequality and threatening the environment. Can it really be that this system is the last word in human organisation and that we can think of nothing better? I don't think so.
First we need to get the myth of "free markets" out of the way. So-called free market are highly regulated markets. The depend on government regulation to create common trading conditions. Furthermore, the post war 'long boom' was achieved in conditions of a high degree of government intervention. And as Mariana Mazzacuto has shown, much of the technical innovation on which we rely has been due to public rather than private initiatives (see her book The Entrepreneurial State). Then think about the NHS as compared with health provision in the US).
So we aleady have in place important elements of an alternative way of doing things and clear evidence (for those ready to look at it) that they work. We need to work with that. Where public provision and organisation can be made more effective than the private altrnatives we should run with that instead of, as at present, dismantling the public sector in the doctrinaire belief that private solutions are always best.
We can make a world which is fairer, more open and gives high quality living standards to everyone. It is high time that we started to do so. There is much in Labour's programme that points in that direction now it needs to work much harder at filling out the details.', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1536656140000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u'you say something original but', u'effect': u"that 's not"}, {u'cause': u'inequality has been reduced', u'effect': u'this is not'}, {u'cause': u'public rather than private initiatives', u'effect': u'and as mariana mazzacuto has shown much of the technical innovation on which we rely has been see'}], u'author_id': u'3477366', u'in_reply_to': u'120299458', u'id': u'120303096', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Nonsuchhouse', u'text': u'MacMillan was a snob and hated Thatcher.She dealt with incentives which is a common problem in the public sector where the cut and thrust of the market giving signals back is lost. Size of budget and queues aren't a good way to judge productivity.Hence the privatisation programme.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1536656006000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'12278244', u'in_reply_to': u'120292934', u'id': u'120302985', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'scubadoc', u'text': u'Yes. Contrary to the article, Nature ALWAYS wins...', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1536655986000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'2000661', u'in_reply_to': u'120286565', u'id': u'120302975', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Erongi', u'text': u'Furthur it was not like Goldman did not have inside knowledge of the true nature of many CDO products including primarily its own,Itwas fined $5 billion in 2015 for misleading clients about the nature of its mortgage backed products sold between 2005 and 2007. They simply knew such products would fail and were prepared to profit from that. That is nothing like normal hedging which is simply a precautionhttps://uk.reuters.com/article/us-goldman-sachs-mbs-settlement-idUKKCN0X81TI', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1536655486000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'12189246', u'in_reply_to': u'120301211', u'id': u'120302602', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'memeroots', u'text': u'Standards such as healthcare, pensions, social net, minimum wage?
All those add costs to our goods but not theirs. 
Appy import duty to equalise the difference.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1536655473000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'12445142', u'in_reply_to': u'120299424', u'id': u'120302590', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'richmanchester', u'text': u'"The real question that should mark the 10th anniversary of the financial crash is a moral one: what was finance for,"

In my experience, the only socialism going on in most western countries is for the very wealthy anyway. Protection of asset ownership via public subsidy.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1536654351000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'11304239', u'in_reply_to': u'120300579', u'id': u'120301798', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Ace1989', u'text': u'BQSTART
I am not sure the additional claims on behalf of the state would fall into the category 'liberal.
BQEND
The claims were already made when the laws were changed to accommodate financiers. This just removes them and shrinks the code of laws.
1. Debt is a contract between the lender and the borrower. Any selling on of that debt should carry the agreement of both the lender and borrower at the time of sale. Efficiency and risk shouldn't only be seen from the perspective of the lender but also the borrower who suffer when third party loan sharks come calling who bought the debt for pennies on the pound.
2. Limited liability is a government protection afforded to capital, basically social insurance. It has no existence outside of that. Its parallel is workers asking for limited liability when they strike, protecting their pay, or landowners asking for limited liability if their properties catch fire, protecting their rent. To enforce all these, you need a big state with bureaucracy. Without it, it doesn't exist.
Liberalism calls for a small state and laws to reflect natural economic incentives. The above laws of limited liability do nothing of the sort but can distort the concept of risk. One could even argue they're socialistic.
