I read in Scientific American today that we may already be past the point where emissions reductions alone can peg warming to 2degrees.', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1536230214000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u'it', u'effect': u'a return of a pro - coal conservative government which would be a disaster'}], u'author_id': u'13793892', u'in_reply_to': u'120132529', u'id': u'120135335', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'aussiejonn', u'text': u'Give it a few years & 500 ppm will show up, Yesterday I received an email from the Mackay conservation group We have been trying to get the Government ( Qld to prosecute Adani) over that port spillage (claimed to be from cyclone Debbie, estimated at more than 800% contamination & all bound for the GBR eventually so the $12.000 odd fine in dispute has now jumped to more than $2mil...However I also note they suggested Adani can not be trusted with the Great Artesian Basin water, the health of the reef, etc & is calling on Bill shorten to cancel their project going into the next fed election.....Bill would know political implications exist so the question is would the rest of Australia make up for those few thousand votes that will be lost...Bill Shorten has got to win Queensland, that in itself is a formidable task...It is the sort of issue that relates directly to global warming & we already know both major parties are not up to speed on climate Change....Although Labor are in a better position almost certainly they will win the next fed election....', u'recommendation_count': u'2', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1536226625000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'12059148', u'id': u'120132529', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Walsunda', u'text': u'"Evidently we are to be told by them" (that is geologists) "that previous periods between ice ages have been so hot that biodiversity on a scale we have now was never possible."
As a geologist who worked on Pleistocene biodiversity changes, I would be interested to know which geologists in which peer reviewed papers published in proper scientific journals told you that "previous periods between ice-ages" (previous interglacials) "have been so hot that biodiversity on a scale we have now was never possible" and what they meant by that. Please provide a reference to such papers.
The Eemian Interglacial or nterglacial previous to the last glacial (or what you might call the last ice age) occurred between 130,000 and 115,000 years ago. The prevailing Eemian climate was, on average, 1 to 2 degrees warmer than the average for the Holocene (last 10,000 years) or in other words fairly close to the temperatures we now experience with current anthropogenic global warming. Sea levels reached 6 to 9 metres higher than today's levels. In my country biodiversity was greater during the Eemian than at present. Humans did not arrive here until around 45,000 years after the end of the Eemian. The Eemian was hotter than the current interglacial pre-anthropogenic global warming because Northern Hemisphere high latitude summer insolation was at a higher peak during the interglacial. This higher NHHLSI caused atmospheric CO2 to reach 290 ppm adding some extra global greenhouse warming.
"So, when in past inter-ice age periods was much hotter than then did an ice age still come."
The Eemian interglacial ended 115,000 yeaers ago and the last "ice-age" or glacial period began because NHHLSI dropped from its Eemian peak to a level sufficient to allow glaciers to advance in the north of North America and the north-west of Eurasia despite CO2 at 290 ppm. Our current NHHLSI is showing a much slower drop off from its peak 19,000 years ago such that at the pre-industrial interglacial CO2 level of 280 ppm it would have until 50,000 years from now for it to reach levels low enough for the next glacial to occur.
"We humans weren't around then yet earth has stilo flipped from much hotter climates to ice age."
Our species has been around 200,000 years and we certainly were around at the time the last Eemian interglacial ended and the last glacial or what you call "ice age" 115,000 years ago.
"Question: who's bullshitting who?"
I'm not bullshitting you and I will give you the benefit of the doubt that the erroneous things you have said above are based on genuine ignorance.', u'recommendation_count': u'2', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1536225370000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u'northern hemisphere high latitude summer insolation was at a higher peak during the interglacial', u'effect': u'the eemian was hotter than the current interglacial pre - anthropogenic global warming'}, {u'cause': u'this higher nhhlsi', u'effect': u'atmospheric co2 to reach 290 ppm adding some extra global greenhouse warming'}, {u'cause': u'nhhlsi dropped from its eemian peak to a level sufficient to allow glaciers to advance in the north of north america and the north west', u'effect': u'the last age began'}], u'author_id': u'12483673', u'in_reply_to': u'120081346', u'id': u'120131523', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'flatspinner7700', u'text': u'Just a few questions, wouldn't the fresh water melt that shuts down AMO induce glaciation as it seems to be a major concern today. Would the cooler waters entering the southern ocean cool the oceans down rather than warming them? Does a CO2 increase of 80 ppm equate to a 4C rise in global temperatures? Lastly, during the Ordovician period, the concentration of CO2 in Earth's atmosphere was about eight times higher than today as the glaciation period of that time occurred -so just wondering of the mechanism of today that would make it impossible for the next ice age to happen. Sorry for so many questions and look forward to your response !', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1536225271000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'100682539', u'in_reply_to': u'120122375', u'id': u'120131436', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Walsunda', u'text': u'What do you mean by "ice ages" and the "summer" between them? I suspect you are referring to the series of Pleistocene glacial and interglacials between them that occurred over the last 2.6 million years. If that's the case, the current interglacial which began 9,000 years ago following 10,000 years of deglaciation which in turn followed 90,000 to 100,000 years of the lastglacial period, would have been a long interglacial compared to its predecessor.
During the last glacial period atmospheric CO2 was at 190 to 200 ppm. 19,000 years ago a peak in Northern Hemisphere high latitude summer insolation (NHHLSI) caused the continental glacial ice sheets that covered northern North America and northwest Eurasia to start melting. The influx of fresh water into the north Atlantic shut down the Atlantic meridional overturning circulation which brings cool water to the Southern Ocean. The temperature of the Southern Ocean consequently rose oxidizing carbon rich oceanic oozes leading to an increase in atmospheric CO2 which caused global greenhouse warming, more melting of the northern continental ice sheets and more global greenhouse warming over the next 10,000 years during which atmospheric CO2 rose from 200 ppm to 280 ppm causing global climate temperature to rise by 4 degrees C.
Since that peak 19,000 years ago NHHLSI has steadily declined while atmospheric CO2 has remained at a typical interglacial level of 280 ppm until the late 19th century when it began to rise reaching current levels in excess of 400 ppm and causing global greenhouse warming. At its current rate of decline NHHLSI and with CO2 at a typical interglacial level of 280 ppm would have reached a level low enough for a glacial period to commence in 50,000 years time. So one in a thousand is likely wildly optimistic.', u'recommendation_count': u'8', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1536037006000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'15131989', u'in_reply_to': u'120053571', u'id': u'120053598', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Erik Frederiksen', u'text': u'"The nice farming-friendly Holocene is coming to an end."
A population of a few million human hunter-gatherers was apparently beyond the carrying capacity of the planet as most places where we showed up the megafauna disappeared.
Around 10-12,000 years ago, when large climate oscillations settled down, we developed agriculture which allowed us to double our population many times into the billions.
But agriculture faces big challenges if we don’t change our ways soon (1), as do our fisheries, and if they both decline significantly, forcing us back to being largely hunter-gatherers, history tells us that out of every 1000 people you see maybe one survives.
1: IPCC Western N America drought 1900-2100 http://icons.wxug.com/hurricane/2013/drought-western-us-1900-2100.png', u'recommendation_count': u'6', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1536036770000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'15131989', u'in_reply_to': u'120049672', u'id': u'120053571', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Erik Frederiksen', u'text': u'Sorry for repeating myself here as I look below.', u'recommendation_count': u'2', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1536034033000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'15131989', u'in_reply_to': u'120053189', u'id': u'120053202', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Erik Frederiksen', u'text': u'Richard Alley mentioned recently that the CO2 change we've accomplished in the last 100 years exceeds the change during the cycles over the last million years of glaciations and interglacials of 180-280ppm which took around 10,000 years.
That's more than 100 times the rate of change we adapted to, and we're continuing our merry way.', u'recommendation_count': u'4', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1536033927000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'15131989', u'in_reply_to': u'120053116', u'id': u'120053189', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'catch18', u'text': u'"if you tried to put recent years on there it would blow off the bottom of the chart a long ways."
Yes Erik. The short term read is indeed blowing off the bottom of these charts. The human effect is so short term and so extreme that it makes these 1500+ year charts not comparable. 
These 1500 year charts are apples. The past fifty years are one big orange bomb. Not trying to be snarky with you here Erik. You know me. But this 1500 year old data charts (In My Very, Very Humble Opinion) can't compare with what we are going through now. I wish I was wrong. And I hope you are right. But humanity has stomped on one nasty hornets nest and the planet is responding so quickly and harshly as to negate long term studies. And if I am wrong I say bless you Erik for being right.', u'recommendation_count': u'7', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1536033372000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'13899889', u'in_reply_to': u'120052922', u'id': u'120053116', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Erik Frederiksen', u'text': u'Ice sheets starting to follow suit, the lines curve downwards indicating acceleration of ice sheet mass loss.

Countries will need to maintain infrastructures for their populations. Hungry people. Angry people. 
The international market's reactions? Initially they will stall. Markets are delicate creatures. Recessions can devolve into a worldwide depression. And the world just keeps on heating. And crop's yield (wheat, rice corn) gets smaller as more babies come online. Bad timing. 
What would help this nasty situation? 
The planet's temperature starts to cool. That would help. C02 starts to diminish instead of going up. That would help. Population begins to decline. That would help. 
Not saying these would solve anything. But they would help.

A new paper indicates just how long lasting will be the impacts from this refusal to listen to scientists: 
BQSTART
By analyzing the fish fossils inside, researchers determined that global temperatures were stable for a long time before the asteroid impact, but then, afterwards, temperatures quickly rose and stayed about 5 degrees Celsius warmer for about 100,000 years. 
MacLeod says it's notable that the impact pumped up carbon dioxide over a short time span that, geologically speaking, is comparable to what humans have been doing in burning fossil fuels since the start of the Industrial Revolution.
"The atmosphere was loaded for a very brief interval of time, and the consequences of that change in atmospheric composition lasted for 100,000 years," MacLeod says. "So it illustrates, I think, really strongly, even if we went back to 1850 levels of carbon dioxide emission, it's going to take a 100,000 years for the carbon dioxide that we've already put in the atmosphere to cycle through the Earth's systems.”
BQEND

Not this time.', u'recommendation_count': u'13', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1536023660000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': None, u'effect': u'the maximum parts per million'}], u'author_id': u'13899889', u'id': u'120052099', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Erik Frederiksen', u'text': u'It is easy to imagine the planet becoming ungovernable from just one likely impact from global warming, the rapid collapse of the West Antarctic Ice Sheet, much less the myriad other impacts.
As the Penn State climate scientist Michael Mann said recently:
"Increasingly, the science suggests that many of the impacts are occurring earlier and with greater amplitude than was predicted," Mann said, after considering new research since the milestone of the IPCC's Fifth Assessment, which served as the scientific basis for the Paris Agreement.
"We have literally, in the space of a year, doubled our assessment of the potential sea level rise we could see by the end of this century. That is simply remarkable. And it is sobering," he said.”

The 800k record is based on several laboratories opening trapped gas of ice by different methods. 
Science is conservative in knowing why ice do compress and flow and enter the statistics of resolution to the extent that on can not make multiple measurements to make it significant in statistics. 
But science also have other tricks - when using proxies to nail it with uncertainty. 
We know pretty well when the CO2 forcing was under 500 ppm (that include uncertainty) last time.
That time is nothing like 800k years it is way longer. 
People who use the 400 to 800,000 year argument are likely stupid and hope that once science produce a 1 million year old record of trapped gas, that theory will instantly reverse.', u'recommendation_count': u'11', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1536011709000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'4706143', u'in_reply_to': u'120049672', u'id': u'120050003', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Erik Frederiksen', u'text': u'If you look at this graph of the last 400,000 years of global temperature, atmospheric CO2 and sea level you’ll notice that only around 4 degrees C separates pre-industrial temperature from that of the glaciations when mile thick ice sheets descended on N America and N Europe.
You’ll also notice how far just our current atmospheric CO2 has blown off the top of the graph; it takes time for temperature and sea level to respond to a climate forcing and we could blow much further off that graph.
The higher we let global temperatures rise, the greater the risk of them going really high due to amplifying feedbacks.', u'recommendation_count': u'11', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1536011474000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'15131989', u'id': u'120049955', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'OhWehGermany', u'text': u'"....with no end in sight."
No end for nature. Nature will shake with laughter and nature history will go on.
But the end of so called human civilization is nearer than we want to know. Every new finding about climate change tells the same story: we underestimated the changes so far, everything develops worse and faster, than we thought yesterday.', u'recommendation_count': u'5', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1536011319000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'17589639', u'id': u'120049921', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'rockyrex', u'text': u'BQSTART
CO2 has reached more than 400ppm, probably the highest for 800,000 years.
BQEND
More likely several million years.
CO2 levels are similar to the Pliocene over 3 million years ago.
Modern humans didn't exist - there was no complex global society relying on stability for agriculture.
Global average temperatures then eventually reached 3 or 4 degrees C (5.4-7.2 degrees F) higher than today’s and as much as 10 degrees C (18 degrees F) warmer at the poles.
Sea level ranged between five and 40 metres (16 to 131 feet) higher than today.
Earth systems take time to respond to forcings.
For example, sea level can't suddenly rise on that scale, because it takes time for enough heat to be accumulated to melt enough ice.
It's worth looking at this paper:
"A human-induced hothouse climate?" - Kidder & Worsley, 2011
The nice farming-friendly Holocene is coming to an end.', u'recommendation_count': u'22', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1536010336000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u'it takes time for enough heat to be accumulated to melt enough ice', u'effect': u"for example sea level ca n't suddenly rise on that scale"}], u'author_id': u'2923581', u'id': u'120049672', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'bluecons', u'text': u'Charles Keeling's CO2 curve by itself:https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Keeling_Curve#/media/File:KeelingCurve-5-26-18.jpg', u'recommendation_count': u'11', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1536009402000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'14514023', u'id': u'120049430', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'JackTheRepairer', u'text': u'And there are still political leaders who deny climate change - mainly because of the lobbyists in fossil fuel industries lining the pockets of the old white men in power.
This will not stop until the governments around the world recognise that today’s greed will hurt everyone tomorrow.
Frack off now.', u'recommendation_count': u'9', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1536008900000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u'the lobbyists in fossil fuel industries lining the pockets of the old white men in power', u'effect': u'and there are still political leaders who deny climate change'}], u'author_id': u'13180932', u'id': u'120049280', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}]
description: Scientist’s measurements begun 60 years ago show relentless rise of CO2 in the atmosphere
headline: O
og_fields.og:description: Scientist’s measurements begun 60 years ago show relentless rise of CO2 in the atmosphere
og_fields.og:title: Weatherwatch: Charles Keeling's CO2 curve shows drastic rise in 60 years
text:
A remarkable run of observations began 60 years ago at a weather station high on a volcano in Hawaii. Charles Keeling began monitoring carbon dioxide in the clean air at 3,400 metres (11,150ft) on Mauna Loa, far away from vegetation and urban pollution. His first measurements in 1958 showed 315 parts per million (ppm) of CO2 in the atmosphere, and what caught him by surprise was that every year after that the levels of CO2 rose relentlessly in an upward curve, thanks to the carbon pollution pumped into the Earth’s atmosphere.
Now the CO2 has reached more than 400ppm, probably the highest for 800,000 years. It sounds a tiny amount of extra CO2, but it is having a huge impact on the climate by trapping more heat on Earth, driving world temperatures upwards. CO2 in the air is now so plentiful that plants are growing fewer leaf pores to absorb the gas than they did centuries ago, and more CO2 is being absorbed into the world’s seas, making them more acidic.
Keeling’s curve of rising CO2 levels is a shocking picture of how much the world’s atmosphere has changed in 60 years, with no end in sight.

description: Prime minister claims Australia will easily meet its obligations without an emissions reduction policy
headline: P
og_fields.og:description: Prime minister claims Australia will easily meet its obligations without an emissions reduction policy
og_fields.og:title: Scott Morrison contradicts energy advice, saying Paris targets can be met 'at a canter'
text:
Scott Morrison is continuing to insist that Australia will meet its Paris climate commitments “in a canter” despite the government having no emissions reduction policies to achieve that result.
The prime minister used a radio interview on Wednesday afternoon to declare “the business-as-usual model gets us there in a canter” – which contradicts advice from the Energy Security Board that says business as usual will mean the electricity sector will “fall short of the emissions reduction target of 26% below 2005 levels”.
Even if the the ESB projections are wrong, and the electricity sector managed to reduce emissions by 26% with no policy to drive that result, the Paris target applies across the economy, not just to the electricity sector, and the government’s own data shows emissions in other sectors of the economy are rising.
Morrison told 2GB on Wednesday that business as usual “and technology and the amount of renewable technologies that are already in the system and not being subsidised off into the future means these [Paris] targets are hit”.
A summary of modelling undertaken by the ESB and released only a month ago said if no policy was put in place in the electricity sector – which is the business-as-usual case the prime minister refers to – emissions would fall initially, then flatten out and rise towards the end of the decade to 2030 as forecast demand increased, then dip again in 2029-30.
The ESB said if the national energy guarantee wasn’t implemented, the national electricity market would “fall short of the emissions reduction target of 26% below 2005 levels”.
On Wednesday the prime minister initially said that the renewable energy target was driving up power prices “and that’s why we are stripping [subsidies] out of the system”, then said later in the same interview that the biggest driver of higher power prices was gold-plating of the electricity networks.
Asked by his host on 2GB what was ultimately more important, complying with Australia’s international climate obligations, or lowering power prices, Morrison said: “Power prices.” He counselled against being “distracted by ideological debate”.
The ESB has warned that if governments fail to implement the national energy guarantee – the policy Malcolm Turnbull shelved to try and stave off the civil war that ultimately cost him the prime ministership – that will “prolong the current investment uncertainty, and deny customers more affordable energy”.
The Neg appears dead, but the government signalled it was interested in trying to implement one component of the policy, the reliability obligation, with the states and territories.
The commonwealth was due to meet with the states and territories in late September to drive the process forward, but the states have yet to be summoned to a meeting to consider what, if any, progress can be made.
The new energy minister, Angus Taylor, is working up a package to take to cabinet for consideration.
With internal sensitivities still raw after the implosion of the last parliamentary fortnight, Morrison has been trying to send a signal that the immediate focus is price relief, while resisting calls from conservatives to withdraw from the Paris agreement.
In attempt to defuse the push, Morrison has been arguing that meeting the Paris commitments will have no tangible impact on power prices.

It is heavier elements that are formed in supernova; atoms are formed in the early universe as it cools, as you know.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1536397169000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'4446531', u'in_reply_to': u'120195893', u'id': u'120197905', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Drfish', u'text': u'Starts with a capital A Arsetralia!, yes the once loved nation who protected it's natural heritage is now a pariah in the developed world, all thanks to the incompetent Liberal/ National Party coalition government. They have managed to make so many species go to the edge of extinction by watering down environmental protections in every area you can imagine, logging mining, land clearing, changing laws and allowing ill educated farmers to "self- assess" their properties before undertaking clearing. To top it all off, they have recently had a change of Prime Minister to one who regularly speaks in tongues ( I kid you not) and who is trying to get out of acting on climate change in any way he can. Yes the Pacific nations are right, it's a nation that starts with a capital A.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1536396983000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'17210000', u'id': u'120197804', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'MieGoreng', u'text': u''Scoal mole', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1536396710000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'4019546', u'in_reply_to': u'120123685', u'id': u'120197683', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'swim2work', u'text': u'The US points to China as the highest annual polluter, and China points to the US as the highest per capita emitter. Strangely, the citizens of both countries appear to be the least worried, but both will be severely impacted by the insanity of climate change. US stands at the top cumulatively and per capita, but is annually #2 because of all the coal fired power stations and the manufacturing relatively recently offlined to China.
We should not forget that fossil fuels are only part of the story, and that meat and dairy have a considerable impact, so it is difficult to apportion blame except in the case of deliberate misinformation, which is now quite obvious and complicit.
Australia has so much desert and should look to the projects now being undertaken by Morocco and others to provide renewable energy to all of Europe. What really bothers me is that people seem to be so focused on greed, when the reality is that the first world countries already live in incredible abundance!
Everything we know is made of atoms, formed in supernova, and everything beyond Earth's biosphere is incredibly violent and hostile. What is it going to take for the world to wake up to the unique biodiversity that we are about to lose and aggressively try to save it, and all that we hold dear? Because without such a commitment we are going to lose it all. A few thousand survivors at the poles, are we really going to accept that?', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1536391660000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'18347751', u'id': u'120195893', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'baselinebob', u'text': u'No that is a a nonsense! what matters to the climate (assuming the warminists are correct, which they may not be BTW) is the total amount of CO)2 in the air, the number of people in each country has absolutely NOTHING to do with the issue. A per capita measure has only one purpose and that is to stimulate "guilt" into residents of first world democracy like our own by suggesting that we are more responsible than the big emitters like China and India who together produce about 50 times more GHG than we do!!!', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1536390461000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'16787174', u'in_reply_to': u'120194340', u'id': u'120195555', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'JEM5260', u'text': u'To make comparisons measure per head of population not the total emissions', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1536381851000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'4776075', u'in_reply_to': u'120125821', u'id': u'120194340', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'MieGoreng', u'text': u'There are many ways to aportion global emissions; absolute yearly emissions and per capita emissions feature prominently. Some fixate on absolute figures where China currently leads (the favorite villain) others fixate on per capita where notable "western" countries lead and points the finger a bit more at lifestyle choices within countries.
A third and important metric is cumulative emissions which perhaps helps rank countries on the overall level of contribution to climate change throughout history - given that climate change started some time ago. See Table (apologies for layout).
Now the usual suspects on this thread are going to spout off about how Australia is such a low contributor (% basis) on this list and the largest offender is the US, so nuffin to do with us. But why do we ape the US response? Why aren't we pressuring the "great ally"? AND lets not forget that we 'export' our emissions. IE emissions are counted in the country that burns coal and gas, not the country that exports the stuff. In the absence of an effective price on carbon emissions this is a failing. 
Australias contribution on this list is ~1% but that still puts us at #15, per capita Australians are carbon gluttons and Australia is the largest international dealer of Coal.
By comparison, the poor people in the Pacific whose islands are increasingly inundated are a tiny fraction of a percent.
So NO Felix, Baseline - they do not share equal responsibility for the problem. 
Figure 6.1. Cumulative CO2 Emissions, 1850–2002Country_______________% of World__________________ (Rank)United States________29.3____________________________(1)EU-25_________________26.5_____________________________(2)Russia_________________8.1_______________________________(3)China__________________7.6_______________________________(4)Germany_____________7.3________________________________(5)United Kingdom___6.3________________________________(6)Japan_________________4.1________________________________(7)France________________2.9_______________________ ________(8).........Australia______________1.1_________________________________(15)', u'recommendation_count': u'2', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1536381704000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'4019546', u'id': u'120194316', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'JEM5260', u'text': u'Grow more trees', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1536380026000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'4776075', u'in_reply_to': u'120142601', u'id': u'120194179', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'JEM5260', u'text': u'Get rid of the LNP', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1536379715000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'4776075', u'id': u'120194146', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'MieGoreng', u'text': u'1. There is more than one issue that voters care about (the hip pocket being the first*).2. Some people are creatures of habit.3. Some candidates lie.

Not SBShttps://www.sbs.com.au/news/paris-agreement-failure-to-cost-australia-126-billion-a-year', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1536370984000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'15880012', u'in_reply_to': u'120156269', u'id': u'120193018', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'R_Ambrose_Raven', u'text': u'Consideration of a regional insurance scheme to help the Pacific islands rebound after natural disasters was recommended a decade ago by a Parliamentary Committee. We could revisit that.
Recall too that abbott joined with Canada in rejecting a decision by the CHOGM summit in Colombo in ’13 to push for a Green Capital Fund (part of a collective 2020 goal that would see $100 billion in what is called climate financing) to help vulnerable island states and poor African countries address the effects of rising sea levels, prolonged droughts, or catastrophic weather incidents, caused by climate change. abbott arrogantly deemed it “socialism masquerading as environmentalism” and a mere wealth transfer from rich countries to poor.
Notwithstanding the semi-official images of mateship, ignoring (sometimes even blaming) the victims of disasters is common, to avoid contributing anything (beyond token media-promoted donations) to their support and guard private property rights against any risk of having to even temporarily share anything. The mentality is similar to that driving vilification of the (boat-borne) asylum-seekers, for similar reasons.
Yet crises such as the 2011 and 2013 floods in Eastern Australia, Fukushima, and earthquake in Christchurch have shown how typically complacent and occasionally arrogant white, middle-class, 'aspirationals' can themselves in an instant become homeless, living ten to a house, no water, no power, dinkum Aussie dunny out the back, like any blackfella's camp. 
While the most well-structured and integrated Pacific states are socially stable in the main, all are now suffering from either or both natural and man-made hazards. 
Denial is a bad approach and a worse solution. But morrison will continue it anyway.', u'recommendation_count': u'2', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1536364945000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u'climate change', u'effect': None}], u'author_id': u'12554246', u'id': u'120192082', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'John Samuel', u'text': u'The ocean is not a gin glass.https://climatechange.environment.harvard.edu/jerry-mitrovica', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1536353219000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'13496713', u'in_reply_to': u'120124822', u'id': u'120189226', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'MieGoreng', u'text': u'It is you that introduced the words "shrinking" and "dissapearing".Your cherry picked paper simply used satellite imagery to estimate areas and found, with large error bars, that some islands may have increased in apparent area. What does that mean? Simply that the redistributed material at least has not been washed into the deep ocean for some islands - yet.
Some islands DID shrink, so I don't know why you think this paper only supports your "not shrinking" assertion. 
The real question is has the frequency if inundation increased and the answer is YES. And this will occur more frequently until they eventually are lost.
https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0921818113001483
https://reliefweb.int/sites/reliefweb.int/files/resources/4_Sea_Level_and_Inundation.pdf', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1536346868000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'4019546', u'in_reply_to': u'120161750', u'id': u'120186843', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'swim2work', u'text': u'Given that AGW (for which we are all responsible) means:
1) a substantial (decades-long) time delay between cause and effect;2) an existential threat to which noone and nowhere is immune;3) climate models do not (and cannot) include all the unknown forcings;4) there is no known way to scrub the atmosphere of CO2;5) the cost of inaction in the long term far exceeds cost of mitigation in the short term;6) a world based on renewable energy has substantial benefits to society.
Isn't increasing worldwide CO2 emissions simply suicidal?Doesn't everyone individually and collectively have an obligation to switch to renewables as rapidly as possible? Don't we have an obligation to ensure that the third world makes the jump to renewables?', u'recommendation_count': u'3', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1536342520000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'18347751', u'id': u'120185047', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'TBombadil', u'text': u'This short-termism is bad policy and will cost in the long run. If we had started to tackle the problem 30 or 40 years ago it would have been a painless and low cost operation spread over many years. Now we not only have to mitigate far more quickly which will make it more costly but we will also have to pay the high cost of adaptation to the long term changes already in the pipeline. 
If we delay the switch from fossil fuels to renewables much longer we will be left with no option but emergency measures. This will entail very costly adaptation measures together with the switching off of all fossil fuel plants more or less overnight. Electricity rationing and power failures will then become the norm for any country that has failed to make the switch to renewable energy in time.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1536330761000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'3382782', u'in_reply_to': u'120123013', u'id': u'120179369', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Carlosthepossum', u'text': u'Thanks Abel, very educational.', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1536328868000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'11915433', u'in_reply_to': u'120160745', u'id': u'120178609', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'gabriela kaplan', u'text': u'All nations must slap TARIFFS on products from USA and any nation who refuses to abide by Paris Accord. To not do so is to bury your head in the sand and not face reality.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1536289945000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u'that', u'effect': u'the deaths of hundreds of thousands of innocent people'}], u'author_id': u'1773518', u'in_reply_to': u'120135422', u'id': u'120161171', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Jas636', u'text': u'The irony in this war against coal in developed countries has made it even cheaper and more profitable for those wanting to use it. As demand and investment falls in the west, the commodity price drops which makes coal power even cheaper. 
Because you aren't competing against large financial institutions who have been pressured not to invest, it's also generating massive returns for those who are can see what is really happening.

In 1997 John Howard hailed President Clinton’s decision to back away from the “hard line” European position on climate change mitigation. He saw it as a victory for the similar Australian position. 
Nauru’s then President, Kinza Clodumar, accused Howard of heavying littoral states at the 1997 South Pacific Forum in Raratonga to weaken greenhouse commitments. He said climate change was the most important issue facing low-lying islands, which feared flooding from rising sea levels associated with global warming. 
In an emotional speech also in 1997 to the high-level ministerial segment of the Kyoto climate change talks, President Clodumar said inaction would be an unspeakable crime against humanity, bringing untold human and ecological misery. His people had been pushed to the coastal fringe of Nauru, a low-lying South Pacific island, by extensive phosphate mining. Now that fringe, just 2m above sea level. was threatened by the rising seas projected under continued global warming. 
“We are trapped ... In the Pacific alone, four other island countries face destruction unless global warming is arrested. Our island brothers and sisters in the Caribbean. Atlantic and Indian oceans face the same desperate plight. We submit respectfully that the wilful destruction or entire countries and cultures with foreknowledge would represent an unspeakable crime against humanity. No nation has a right to place its own misconstrued national interest before the fiscal and cultural survival of whole countries.”', u'recommendation_count': u'9', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1536237195000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'12554246', u'id': u'120141014', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'ID9766495', u'text': u'Big surprise you won't take responsibility for what you've done either', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1536235977000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'3333597', u'in_reply_to': u'120138769', u'id': u'120139838', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'seppowatcher', u'text': u'The statement can be read two ways, its another point of view but its not clear who is right.

"While we recognise that habitability rests on a number of factors, loss of land is unlikely to be a factor in forcing depopulation of Tuvalu." The study's authors said island nations needed to find creative solutions to adapt to climate change that take into account their homeland's evolving geography. Suggestions included moving populations onto larger islands and atolls, which have proved the most stable and likely to grow as seas rise. "Embracing such new adaptation pathways will present considerable national scale challenges to planning, development goals and land tenure systems," they said. description: PM of Tuvalu said a country ‘starting with capital A’ wanted qualifications made to a communique on climate change and emissions
headline: l
og_fields.og:description: PM of Tuvalu said a country ‘starting with capital A’ wanted qualifications made to a communique on climate change and emissions
og_fields.og:title: Australia tried to water down climate change resolution at Pacific Islands Forum: leader
text:
Australia attempted to water down a resolution on climate change agreed by country representatives at the Pacific Islands Forum, a leader attending the event has claimed.Pacific leaders issued the Boe declaration on Wednesday night, calling climate change “the single greatest threat to the livelihoods, security and wellbeing of the peoples of the Pacific” at the conclusion of the Pacific Islands Forum, which has been held in Nauru this week.
However the forum communique – which focused heavily on climate change and the need for emissions reductions – was endorsed by leaders “with qualification”.
When asked at a press conference if those qualifications came from a country “beginning with A”, Enele Sopoaga, the prime minister of Tuvalu, confirmed that “the name of the qualifier, seeking qualifications [started] with capital A”.
Australia is the only nation in the Pacific to fit this description.It appears Australia also did not support a section of agreement calling on the United States to return to the Paris agreement on climate change.
The communique made it clear that it was only “leaders of forum island countries” – a term that a forum spokesperson confirmed denoted all forum member countries other than Australia and New Zealand – who called on the US to return to the Paris agreement on climate change.
A spokesperson from the New Zealand Ministry of Foreign Affairs and Trade said: “I can confirm that NZ absolutely supports the reference in the communique calling for the US to return to the Paris agreement.”
Guardian Australia has sought comment from the Australian Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade.Sopoaga said it was essential the US return to the agreement and commit to reducing emissions.“We cannot have comprehensive robust emissions reductions unless the biggest emitter is there in the process, we cannot leave the US out, they are responsible for 25% of global emissions,” he said.
The Boe declaration committed all forum countries to meeting their Paris agreement targets – a question of fierce domestic political debate in Australia.
“Leaders reaffirmed the importance of immediate urgent action to combat climate change and … called on countries, particularly large emitters, to fully implement their … mitigation targets,” the declaration said.
The president of host nation Nauru, Baron Waqa, said despite the fact the declaration included a qualification from Australia “that doesn’t make it any weaker”.
But the Australian government’s apparent ambivalence towards a low-emissions climate policy has disquieted its Pacific neighbours.
Low-lying island Pacific countries including Kiribati are forecast to be among the first on the planet to disappear underwater if rising sea levels are not arrested.Australia’s attempts to resist the strong language in the Boe declaration fits with its past behaviour at international meetings, according to a Pacific climate change representative who has represented his nation at COP summits for the last five years.Speaking to Guardian Australia ahead of the Pacific Islands Forum, Xavier Matsutaro, the national climate change coordinator for Palau, in the north-west Pacific, said Australia was “responsible for making our declarations weaker sometimes in the region”.“So there’s been forums that were formulated so [Australia] won’t be involved in it, they’re not members, so that whatever language that really reflects our views and our circumstances is actually reflected in the declaration,” he said.
He also likened Australia to an "abusive spouse", saying Australia provided aid to the region to deal with the effects of global warming but undermining attempts to halt its progress.
Additional reporting by Charles Anderson

description: Protests against politicians’ failure to tackle the environmental crisis will take place in more than 90 countries
headline: l
og_fields.og:description: Protests against politicians’ failure to tackle the environmental crisis will take place in more than 90 countries
og_fields.og:title: Hundreds of thousands expected to join global climate marches this weekend
text:
Hundreds of thousand of people in more than 90 countries are expected to take part in demonstrations this weekend to protest about the failure of politicians to tackle the global environmental crisis.
Organisers say more than 800 events – from marches to street theatre, acts of civil disobedience to mini festivals – will take place in towns and cities amid growing frustration at the lack of meaningful political action over the emerging climate breakdown.
Nick Bryer from campaign group 350.org which is organising the event said: “Politicians are failing. They are still protecting the interests of the fossil fuel companies over the interests of people, despite mounting evidence of the devastation these companies and this system is causing the planet.”
He said the day of global demonstrations was about people around the world “rising up and demanding a different cause of action, a different future which puts people and a sustainable future before the interests of these huge corporations”.
In the UK there are events organised in cities from London to Wigan, Bradford to Durham.
Jane Thewlis, from Fossil Free West Yorkshire, is organising an event in Bradford.
“We have a brilliant jazz band the Peace Artistes which are well known round here and the focus is divestment and a celebration of what has already been achieved from New York to Ireland.”
Thewlis said the group were campaigning to persuade the five West Yorkshire councils to divest their pension funds from fossil fuels and hoped the event would galvanise support – especially among young people.
“There will be several young people speaking, many of them associated with a group called Hope Rising which is based on a local council estate.”
Thewlis said the same policies that are damaging the lives of poor people in Bradford were driving the destruction of the planet and killing marginalised people around the world.
We would like to hear from you if you are taking part in any of the weekend's events or involved in organising where you live, and will highlight some of your contributions in our coverage. You can also share pictures and stories from the events you attend. 
Get in touch via this encrypted form. One of our journalists may be in contact and we will consider some of your responses in our reporting. You can read terms of service here.
“These young people are making those links, and that’s why we have specifically got young, working class people of colour to talk on Saturday. We hope that these young people will form their own environmental group following the event and build a sustainable movement.”
One of the biggest protests is expected in Paris where up to 100,000 people are expected. Events in other European cities including Copenhagen, Brussels and Lisbon are also expected to attract tens of thousands of protesters.
The events come ahead of the Global Climate Action Summit that starts in San Fransisco next week and will see politicians and city leaders from around the world gather to discuss the climate crisis.

I shall check it out.
One of the strong themes in the research I am doing, is about the fact that climate change is the biggest market failure in the history of the world. 
When corporations cost their products, they compile all of the costs to the organisation of producing that product or providing that service. But because in Australia we briefly, but only briefly, forced corporations to cost their harm to the environment, corporations have not included the real costs of their products or services, because they have totally ignored the costs to the environment. 
This is where the market has been a spectacular failure - not my words but the words of Sir Nicholas Stern a very respected UK economist who advises the Tory government. When we had an EIS, for the first and last time, corporations had to actually account for the true costs or producing their product or providing their service, which included the costs to the environment, the harms to human health, the exploitation of workers and the communities they did business in, the rising costs associated with global warming such as infrastructure, crop and stock losses, flood and droughts etc. For the first and last time, this served the very important 'polluter pays' principle. 
But along comes Abbott and he gives corporations permission to poluute for absolutely free once again, and ensures the market continues to fail 'spectacularly' once again.
As a Liberal Party that is happy to try to force coporations to keep coal stations working into their twighlight years and force corporations to make losses on the fossil fuel product they are producing, due to the age of the plant and the inefficiencies such as when it breaks down, yet it is unhappy to actually enforce market rules that are their usual Bible, in the form of the 'polluter pays' principle. What does this Liberal Party stand for?
We have Abbott again today advocating for the removal of subsidies for renewable energy - well I don't mind that, BUT so long as they also cancel the $4B of fossil fuel corporation subsidies they are paying. Lets make it an even playing field and let the market decide - coal or renewables. 
But no, the market Gods in the Liberal Party are only too happy to play with market factors when it suits them, such as giving an unfair advantage to fossil fuels, forcing AGL to keep coal going or sell their Liddell coal plant to another company who will keep coal going, and forcing fossil fuel corporations to reduce their prices and guarantee electricity supply, and threatening them all with a big stick if they don't comply with these unreasonable government demands, but then claim not to be able to interfere in the market when the market fails so terribly.
Hypocritical and criminally negligent - this will be the subject of my next thesis.', u'recommendation_count': u'3', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1536649485000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u'the age of the plant and the inefficiencies such as when it breaks down', u'effect': u'as a liberal party that is happy to try to force coporations to keep coal stations working into their twighlight years and force corporations to make losses on the fossil fuel product they are producing yet it is unhappy to actually enforce market rules that are their usual bible'}], u'author_id': u'17134571', u'in_reply_to': u'120298790', u'id': u'120299337', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Walsunda', u'text': u'When I grew up in Brisbane the good country folk of Queensland had three times the electoral power despite being a minority of the state's population. If only we could grow enough of the stuff to clean up with these world beating prices.', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1536634288000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'12483673', u'in_reply_to': u'120246093', u'id': u'120295653', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Walsunda', u'text': u'With 100% of New South Wales drought declared and all of Southern Queensland west of the Great Divide. this bit of the Earth is red or black and most certainly not green. By means of photosynthesis and sunlight plants make there own food from CO2 from the air and H2O from the soil. There's always enough CO2 in the air but in drought times there's not enough H20 in the soil for plants to make their own food. Hence the current record wheat prices as drought cuts supply.
https://www.smh.com.au/business/market/d rought-sends-australian-wheat-on-a-world-beating-rally-20180802-p4zv1d.html
"After consecutive years of bumper harvests, global wheat output is set to fall to a three-year low on smaller crops in Europe, the Black Sea and the first drop in Russian output in six years. Australia June predicted wheat production at 21.9 million tonnes, is about 3 percent bigger than last year's harvest, which was the smallest in a decade. National Australia Bank warned last month that output could fall below 20 million tonnes due to 'tough' growing conditions in many parts of the country."
""'The persistent dry weather in Australia's north-east has cut summer grain production, and that means that 2018 winter crops are likely to be modest at best,' said Tobin Gorey, a strategist at the Commonwealth Bank of Australia. 'Adding to the tightness of in demand for food in eastern Australia. When/if this happens we can proceed to rational discussion and action on carbon emissions pricing and reductions.', u'recommendation_count': u'2', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1536628350000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u'this whole issue is framed by vested interests', u'effect': u'at this point in time any carbon emissions reductions are no longer a question of policy or of deciding on the right policy'}], u'author_id': u'15608068', u'id': u'120294570', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Walsunda', u'text': u'The not so refreshing change in name from the Country Party to the National Party occurred at the height of power of the South African National Party before most of that country's people were allowed to vote.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1536627014000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'12483673', u'in_reply_to': u'120247084', u'id': u'120294288', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'ClHawk', u'text': u'Thanks for this excellent post.', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1536626787000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'14154918', u'in_reply_to': u'120293171', u'id': u'120294246', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Walsunda', u'text': u'Barnaby still denies climate change has anything to do with weather extremes. Ignoring research that shows global greenhouse warming is increasing the frequency of extreme La Nina events and after his temporary Queensland home town of St George was flooded twice in twelve months during the 2010-11 La Nina, Barnaby went back to the cooler and drier climes south the border of in New England. Now it's drier than he bargained for. Global warming increases the rate of onset and hence the length of droughts, as well as the frequency of extreme El Nino droughts circa 2015-16, as well as keeping rain bearing Southern Ocean lows south of the continent.', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1536626763000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'12483673', u'in_reply_to': u'120253887', u'id': u'120294241', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'ClHawk', u'text': u'It's good to see farmers coming in board with climate change. This could make a huge difference to politics in the regions. Farmers should be right at the front of action on climate change.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1536626519000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'14154918', u'id': u'120294191', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'JusticeRules', u'text': u'I sympathise with enlightened farmers. I apologise in advance for those farmers to whom my post does not apply. Those whose heads are not stuck in their cracked earth that used to be pastures. I sincerely feel for you and I am very much on your side.
Sadly, the reason we currently have no action on climate change is because farmers have persisted in voting for the Nationals who are climate change deniers. From a vote of 2% of the total Australian primary vote, 18 national Party MPs, (10% of MPs) were elected to the House. In comparison, the Greens had a national primary vote of 11% and only managed to get 1 MP, (0.17%), elected to the House. If not all, most of the Nationals MPs are rampant climate change deniers and coal hungry neanderthals. The LNP only got into power thanks to these 18 Nationals seats. Once again, the Nationals and a handful of their Liberal counterparts have forced the LNP to back down on any action on climate change, as tiny as even that action was going to be. Abbott and the Nationals got rid of the Gillard government that was taking excellent action on climate change. Now were are 10 further years down the line, and the Nationals are still at it.
What these farmers with their heads in their drought ravaged land won't accept, is that the Greens, and to a lesser extent Labor, have had farmers backs right throughout. It is only the Greens who have supported farmers' Lock the Gate movements. But NO farmer I know would vote Greens, even if they were the last Party on earth - this is purely for ideological reasons, based mainly on total ignorance and misinformaiton about what the Greens stand for and their actual policies, which few if any of these farmers have ever attempted to familiarise themselves with. They would much prefer to take the word of the alt-right media, that the Greens are bad for farmers.
If these farmers are so good at what they do, then why do they keep voting in people like Barnaby Joyce who has never lifted a finger for his constituents. He sat by when coal mines were approved on prime agricultural land. He helped a couple of rich cotton farmers, who have now been indicted for their $20 million water theft, steal the water that belonged to thousands of farming families down stream of Queensland. He held onto funding that had been approved to assist farmers last time there was a massive drought issue and farm families were going under, so long, that many families had to leave their land as they received no assistance in time. Barnaby votes against any assistance to farmers for climate change mitigation. He refused to assist farmers to move to a chilled meat trade, such that every time there is a live export scandal, all hell breaks lose and live export is banned and farmers suffer as a result. But in amongst all these failures to farmers, he threatened to kill two innocent dogs who posed zero threat to farmers, and bring disgrace, pain and embarrassment to his suffering family because he couldn't even live up to his own self professed standards of morality.
Farmers would rather elect MPs like Matt Canavan who doesn't care about the impact on farmers of more coal being burned in a country, that is already suffering severely from the burning of coal. Matt Canavan won't be happy until every bit of farmland is dug up in the pursuit of coal, and every local rural town is decimated by FIFO workers, and every bit of Australian land and property is covered with a thick coat of coal dust. He doesn't care about farmer's families who will suffer life threatening, and shortening, respiratory disease due to the coal dust influx. He doesn't care that rivers and creeks that farmers rely on, will be poisoned with coal dust and chemical tailings. He doesn't care that food crops will become inedible due to coal mine run off and coal dust. And he doesn't care that the continued burning of coal in Australia will result in more drought, floods, damaging storms, and deaths of innocent Australians. Yet these farmers, representing a mere 2% of Australians, will still saddle all Australians with Canavan's, and his mates', climate change denial for another 6 years, at the next election.
These 2% of farmers have saddled Australia with a government, and with 18 MPs who are criminally negligent, and we are ALL suffering as a result. Even the National Farmers Federation has finally seen the light go on in their collective heads, that climate change is causing major issues for farmers, only about 40 years too late, but at least they are now on side. But these 2% of Australians, farmers with their heads buried in the sand that used to be their grass pastures, will keep putting Australia's future in peril - just how smart are they, really???

They need to stop pandering to mining companies and start engaging in worthwhile activities to help farmers, and that does not mean cutting foreign aid, it means investment in renewable energy to help fight climate change.', u'recommendation_count': u'3', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1536599068000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'11575149', u'id': u'120283913', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Wayne Here', u'text': u'The 'cant do anything so why bother' is a tool usually used by those who want to continue to mine or extract fossil fuels like there is no tomorrow. To make more money of course.Climate change is already contributing to over 400,000 deaths and costing the world more than $1.2 trillion each year. How? Just look at the devastation in the wake of Superstorms, fires and droughts. In each case worldwide, the horrifying list of injuries and fatalities was just the beginning, as businesses and the communities that relied on them struggled to get back on their feet long after the rescue crews and television cameras left. Here’s the flipside: decarbonizing the electricity system would save US$1.8 trillion over the coming two decades. Lose US$1.2 trillion or save US$1.8 trillion? It’s not a trick question.If we act now to swiftly transition from dirty fossil fuels to clean energy, there’s a chance we could limit warming to 2 degrees Celsius. If we do nothing, and continue on the path we’re on, the temperature could rise over 6 degrees Celsius by early next century. The difference between these two scenarios is dramatic.We’re already feeling the effects of climate change. But that’s precisely why weneed to both prepare for the climate change impacts we can’t avoid and act quicklyto cut the carbon pollution that’s causing the problem — and could make it worse.It’s not an either/or decision — we need to do both. The longer we wait to make thetransition to clean energy, the worse this problem will get for our children and future generations.It’s our choice.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1536595414000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u'\u2019s', u'effect': u'that'}], u'author_id': u'15055115', u'in_reply_to': u'120258953', u'id': u'120281610', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Wayne Here', u'text': u'We are in the top handful of producers of CO2 per capita and getting worse by lack of effort from our current pollies. description: As farmers we’re dealing with increasingly extreme weather as a result of global warming. We need meaningful action now
og_fields.og:description: As farmers we’re dealing with increasingly extreme weather as a result of global warming. We need meaningful action now
og_fields.og:title: Dear politicians, get your heads out of the coal pit and into the real world | Peter Holding
text:
As a third-generation farmer from Harden in New South Wales, I’ve weathered climate extremes my whole life. It’s simply part of doing business in one of the most variable climates in the world.
The truth is, Australian farmers are good at what they do, and we know when things are changing.
NSW last year was 2 degrees above the baseline average, without an El Niño in sight. This year we’ve already seen 100% of the state drought-declared. The minimal amount of winter crop that has sprouted is sizzling on the stalks or bitten hard by severe -5C frosts. To the north the dams are parched and farmers across the state are close to walking off the land.
It’s not just the farmers, either. In the past five years, my local town, amalgamated against the wishes of the local population, has struggled to keep council staff. We have seen a local bank and a favourite watering hole close. We are about to lose our Landcare facilitator who has been a critical element in natural resource management, sustainable farming and drought support.
We can and must do better.
This is not a “hard-done-by farmer” narrative. We’re tough and we manage our resources carefully, making decisions based upon the best available evidence and always keeping one eye to the future. This is an area with a long history of working with scientists and advisers to be prepared for future agricultural, environmental and economic shocks.
But, the first step to managing for the future is to grapple with reality. And the reality is that our climate is on a devastating trajectory. Much as our politicians like to deny reality, out here – beyond the air-conditioned hallways of parliament – we’re already dealing with increasingly extreme weather as a result of global warming.
So, a message to our elected representatives. Get your heads out of the coalpit and back into the real world. We need meaningful action now; including support for regional communities and funding for Landcare facilitators to be driving up driveways and checking on those whose lives are being destroyed by your failure to take action. We need a good heavy dose of reality injected into Australian politics.
On Monday, my fellow farmers and I will stand outside parliament and rally for our future. A future in which our kids have a chance to farm and our government no longer hides from the truth.
The alternative is simply unthinkable.
• Peter Holding is a mixed cropping and sheep producer with 40 years’ experience on his family farm

In my experience, most perceived 'well known' differences between the political left and right don't actually exist.
BQEND
Agreed: the differences frequently seem manufactured and grossly exaggerated, in order to bolster the sense of identity as you suggest. I regret this very much since it seems to me that it would be better to base a political edifice on what the polity have in common, rather than the divisive search for those 'well-known' differences. However, this is one of the major pitfalls of adversarial systems, which I regard as wasteful and counter-productive in most instances.
This fabrication of difference leads inevitably to polarisation and demagoguery, since the former is the objective and the latter is the preferred method of the vested interests promoting division. I am frequently amused by American notions of domestic socialism (although less amused by their rampant terror of it) when, in this European view, the US system has about as much to do with socialism as Blair's Labour party i.e. none.
As for Churchill, he also said that the best argument against democracy was 'a five-minute conversation with the average voter'. Such arguments as "we can't change things" or "it's too late" are frequently heard from Republicans or even the old "China is worse" argument. This is a crucial political difference between the two parties and their voters. 
Your quote focused on the similarity across party lines but the study itself came up with the following:
"Sixty-six percent of Republicans, 74 percent of Independents and 90 percent of Democrats said they believed in human-caused climate change and the utility of reducing greenhouse gases." 
There is a big difference between 66% and 90%. And even among the 90% of Democrats who believe in the "utility" of greenhouse gas reduction there will also be those who would prefer that nothing impinge on their own lives. Both Republicans and Democrats in congress and the senate are political prostitutes, and do largely what their backers pay them to do, not what is right, or what is needed. The obstacle - insurmountable until it's too late e.g. when it is impossible to deny we've broken the environment - is ideological entrenchment and the growing polarisation between the very people you think should be getting together. Another way of putting this is that you recommend people should waste their time - not a very sensible suggestion in my view - rather like thinking that somehow it might be possible to change the mind one of our resident deniers. I personally wrote about climate change for a decade, and in all that time I don't think I can claim a single convert.
BQSTART
My point is that it is not just politically naive, but almost suicidally reckless to leave such a critical issue as AGW to party politics.
BQEND
I agree, except that the real obstacle isn't party politics, but democracy. No country with a short electoral cycle, ignorant and divided electorates (many of whom don't bother to vote - Australia at least gets this right through mandatory voting) and campaign finance laws like Citizens United, can address long-term issues like climate change. This is, of course, just my opinion, but it is supported by some evidence: the country doing the most about climate change is China, a dictatorship that makes long-term plans in the knowledge that no matter how unpopular, they can't be voted out of office.
You also mention certainty. There is only one thing that's absolutely certain about life, and that's how it will end. All else is punditry, and (rather like too much of this post) nothing at all to do with the topic.', u'recommendation_count': u'6', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1536824345000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'2947466', u'in_reply_to': u'120368893', u'id': u'120384833', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'ComfortablyPlumb', u'text': u'Republicans and Democrats agree on climate change — they just don't realize it"Surveying 2,000 adults, the research team found that, across party lines, there is general agreement that climate change is real, that it is caused by human activity and that something should be done to mitigate it.
The study further reveals that people are more likely to support the same climate policy proposal when they think that their own political party supports it — and that both Democrats and Republicans overestimate how much their peers oppose the ideas of the other party.
“Democratic and Republican citizens alike evaluate a carbon tax or cap and trade policy based on who proposed it — above and beyond their thoughts on the details of the policy, or on whether it is consistent with their beliefs about the importance of climate change,” said David Sherman, a UC Santa Barbara professor of psychological and brain sciences and senior author on the paper. “They do this despite stating themselves that policy considerations should be more important than partisanship."

description: Dana Nuccitelli: Kavanaugh thinks Congress should address climate change. That’s true, but it doesn’t lessen EPA’s authority
headline: l
og_fields.og:description: Dana Nuccitelli: Kavanaugh thinks Congress should address climate change. That’s true, but it doesn’t lessen EPA’s authority
og_fields.og:title: Kavanaugh’s views on EPA’s climate authority are dangerous and wrong | Dana Nuccitelli
text:
Donald Trump’s latest Supreme Court nominee Brett Kavanaugh accepts that humans are causing global warming and we need to take action to stop it. The problem is that he doesn’t trust the experts at EPA to do so and wants to erode their authority to regulate carbon pollution.
When discussing Chevron and climate change, we usually focus on the company’s legal liability. However, in Kavanaugh’s context, ‘Chevron deference’ is even more important. The term refers to the fact that courts will generally defer to government agency interpretations of laws as long as Congress hasn’t spoken directly to the issue at hand.
David Doniger, director of the climate and clean air program at the Natural Resources Defense Council noted that Kavanaugh doesn’t believe Chevron deference applies on issues of major importance. In a recent net neutrality case, Kavanaugh argued, “While the Chevron doctrine allows an agency to rely on statutory ambiguity to issue ordinary rules, the major rules doctrine prevents an agency from relying on statutory ambiguity to issue major rules.”
That’s Kavanaugh’s position on climate change. In oral arguments before his DC Circuit Court of Appeals in a 2016 Clean Power Plan case, Kavanaugh said:
This is huge case … it has huge economic and political significance … it’s fundamentally transforming an industry by telling existing units you in essence have to pay a penalty, a huge financial penalty in order to continue to exist, in order to shift from coal plants to solar and wind plants, at the same time the coal mining industry is in essence greatly harmed, as well.
But while regulating carbon pollution would have a major impact on the fossil fuel industry, the same is true of most pollutant regulations. It’s nevertheless EPA’s job to regulate pollutants, and the agency has been doing exactly that since its inception.
In the 2016 oral arguments, Kavanaugh said that the Clean Air Act is “a thin statute, it wasn’t designed with [greenhouse gases and climate change] specifically in mind.” But EPA was created to address various types of pollution, and the Clean Air Act gave it that legal authority. As the Act’s text notes:
the growth in the amount and complexity of air pollution brought about by urbanization, industrial development, and the increasing use of motor vehicles, has resulted in mounting dangers to the public health and welfare
The Clean Air act also defined the term “air pollutant” very broadly to allow EPA the flexibility to regulate any new sources of pollution that the agency might identify in the future:
The term “air pollutant” means any air pollution agent or combination of such agents, including any physical, chemical, biological, radioactive (including source material, special nuclear material, and byproduct material) substance or matter which is emitted into or otherwise enters the ambient air.
And it gave the EPA Administrator the authority to regulate any pollutants that threaten public health and welfare:
For the purpose of establishing national primary and secondary ambient air quality standards, the Administrator shall within 30 days after December 31, 1970, publish, and shall from time to time thereafter revise, a list which includes each air pollutant … emissions of which, in his judgment, cause or contribute to air pollution which may reasonably be anticipated to endanger public health or welfare
The Clean Air Act even envisioned EPA’s regulatory authority extending to impacts on the climate:
All language referring to effects on welfare includes, but is not limited to, effects on soils, water, crops, vegetation, manmade materials, animals, wildlife, weather, visibility, and climate…
In the landmark 2007 case Massachusetts v. EPA, the Supreme Court affirmed that greenhouse gases qualify as air pollutants, and EPA therefore has authority to regulate them if the agency determines that they may endanger public health or welfare. In its 2009 Endangerment Finding, that was indeed EPA’s conclusion:
greenhouse gases in the atmosphere may reasonably be anticipated both to endanger public health and to endanger public welfare .... The major assessments by the U.S. Global Climate Research Program (USGCRP), the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC), and the National Research Council (NRC) serve as the primary scientific basis supporting the Administrator’s endangerment finding.
In a key 2014 case Utility Air Regulatory Group v. EPA, the Supreme Court ruled 7 to 2 that EPA can continue to treat greenhouse gases as pollutants subject to regulation under the Clean Air Act and can apply those regulations to power plants. Justices Scalia, Roberts, and Kennedy joined the majority decision. The good news is that Scalia’s position in this case was modeled after a prior Kavanaugh opinion.
But generally speaking, Kavanaugh doesn’t trust the EPA experts to regulate carbon pollution.
In the 2016 oral arguments before his court, Kavanaugh laid out his case for why Congress, not the EPA should tackle climate change:
Earth is warming, and humans are contributing, and I understand the international collective action problem here, I understand that very well, and I understand the frustration with Congress, I live that, too, everyone understands that. But under our system of separation of powers, and this is why it’s so important that we maintain that, Congress is supposed to make the decision. You might say, you know, this Congress is not going to, they’re not going to do anything, but that’s not how we get to make decisions … for a big question like this Congress can do things like job training programs, and community college assistance, and welfare assistance, and drug programs for the people who are out of work, and that becomes more of a problem, that’s why the separation of powers principle matters, because Congress can look at something like this in a well-rounded approach, and that was the difficulty obviously that happened in the Senate. But for us to do it, for you to do it, all the people who are left behind are just left behind.
Kavanaugh is right that Congress could and should do a better job tackling carbon pollution than EPA. For example, Hillary Clinton developed plans to both tackle climate change and help coal communities adapt. But Republicans in the White House and Congress are owned by the fossil fuel industry, and thus unwilling to advance serious climate legislation.
However, the fact that Congress won’t act as long as Republicans are in charge doesn’t lessen EPA’s authority to regulate carbon pollution. Kavanaugh’s unwillingness to defer to EPA’s legal authority is wrong. The Clean Air Act is very clear that EPA should regulate pollutants that may endanger public health and welfare, and greenhouse gases certainly qualify.
If Kavanaugh is seated on the Supreme Court, he’ll join the other conservative justices in eroding EPA’s ability to regulate carbon pollution. EPA won’t take serious action until there’s a Democrat in the White House anyway; nor will Congress act unless Democrats are in charge of that branch of government. Kavanaugh just represents one more Republican obstruction to climate action.
