Both are obstructionist.', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1537446802000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'3026692', u'in_reply_to': u'120613396', u'id': u'120636732', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'erenata', u'text': u'Since you are reducing it to an us and them issue, why on earth would I wish to drive my car into your city..if I wished to be there, I would not be living in my beautiful environment in the first place.', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1537444978000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'14430328', u'in_reply_to': u'120631810', u'id': u'120635330', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Veronica22b', u'text': u'"Also for Londoners as well as diesel particulates and brake and tyre particulates "Fair point, it is not just the engine that generates dust and particulates although I suspect the polution from those other sources from vehicles is far lower (it would be interesting to see some research on the subject). A small chunk of optimism for you to cling to though - electric vehicles could (and probably some do) use the motor to brake while also returning energy to the battery. Much like braking on the engine with internal combustion vehicles, only more so because the engine will be exerting more resitance than just friction since it is transfering energy back to the battery.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1537442059000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u'the engine will be exerting more resitance than just friction since it is transfering energy back to the battery', u'effect': u'much like braking on the engine with internal combustion vehicles only more so'}], u'author_id': u'17433782', u'in_reply_to': u'120587156', u'id': u'120633018', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Magnusreputo', u'text': u'https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2018/sep/17/germany-launches-worlds-first-hydrogen-powered-train', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1537353265000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'16388350', u'in_reply_to': u'120590451', u'id': u'120590842', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'drprl', u'text': u'Sounds good - pressure for the tightest limit on pollution to fit all the rules.', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1537441004000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'3026692', u'in_reply_to': u'120626552', u'id': u'120632203', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'drprl', u'text': u'Cities are an efficient way of housing people who need/want to interact. If you want to live on a remote croft and be self-sufficient fine - but don't drive a polluting car into our city.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1537440514000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'3026692', u'in_reply_to': u'120570878', u'id': u'120631810', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Magnusreputo', u'text': u'Diesel & Petrol powered vehicles create toxic air, full of carbon monoxide and tiny diesel particulates that damage us all.
Unfortunately battery powered vehicles are not the answer, the batteries weigh up to 600Kg, use exotic toxic materials to manufacture, have a limited life with huge disposal problems & plugging them all in to recharge is a logistical nightmare beset with many impracticalities in an urban environment.Interesting that Japan now moving towards a fully Hydrogen powered economy, producing hydrogen using renewable 'wrong time' energy, storing it & able to completely refuel a hydrogen powered Mirai car in around 3 minutes. Producing no pollution or particulates.https://www.japan.go.jp/tomodachi/2016/spring2016/tokyo_realize_hydrogen_by_2020.html', u'recommendation_count': u'5', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1537352791000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'16388350', u'id': u'120590451', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'bargie', u'text': u'Wow, letting facts get into a story that is all about driving up the tax take from transport, again.Excellent post.', u'recommendation_count': u'2', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1537352510000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'11739803', u'in_reply_to': u'120575753', u'id': u'120590217', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'drprl', u'text': u'So running more frequent trains would be a feasible solution ? If already packed that would produce more revenue from people like you who are squeezed out at the moment. Perhaps better cycle infrastructure would entice some from the crowded trains which would probably be a cheaper solution.', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1537440291000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'3026692', u'in_reply_to': u'120571116', u'id': u'120631659', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'FRENCHPETRA', u'text': u'Think global,act local ",we tried since over 40 years,if transport doesn't turn green now,it's too late...now breathing masks at night,soon during day....', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1537435575000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'12178759', u'id': u'120628188', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'bargie', u'text': u'The lungs of our citizens are now a concern of many, and quite right.
Therefore please advise us what measures/taxes are proposed to enable significant reductions of the following pollutants; airborne tree and grass pollen, the products of combustion of any heating and cooking device that actually vents pollution directly into the home as well as the atmosphere.
The dust that blows up from the Sahara is also a concern of many and we are hopeful that a solution for that is anticipated, perhaps decent disposable masks could be issued to all who exposed when a certain level is reached.
Cats and dogs also present a significant asthma trigger in many children, presumably they will be banned forthwith from the home.
We must be told when these actions are to be carried out.', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1537352127000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'11739803', u'id': u'120589894', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Hermanovic', u'text': u'It doesn't help that the way air pollution is being regulated can only be described as pure chaos. Every city makes up it's own rules, and governments and the EU have their own policies on top of that. 
It won't be long until we need 15 different 'green stickers' on our cars, so we can travel 100 miles without getting a fine.', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1537433417000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'12131015', u'id': u'120626552', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'btt1943', u'text': u'Verily, the past summer has been one of the worst, if not the most extreme, in Japan's climate record. Things have to be expedited to arrest any further increase of green house gases in the atmosphere now, lest regret later. But some rich countries' leaders simply refuse to take note, pretending that they do not know (actually they could not be bothered at all) the ultimate product of lavish affluence is waste-heat that warms the environment perpetually. Farcically preposterous.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1537411060000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'11223385', u'id': u'120620151', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Stevencharles71', u'text': u'I believe some containers will be transported on smaller ships, so with that option already in mind, that could be a solution. I think the operation is too big for the area of it's location, Sefton, so several simultaneous solutions are probably necessary, your suggestions being two. 
The one important factor when planning construction projects this century in the UK, should be a legal obligation to consider the consequences of what you can construct and how you construct it, with a necessity to explore the engineering capabilities and think long term. At the moment the objective seems to be what is the cheapest short term solution, which in this case is an open road at a cost of £300 million, rather than a tunnel at a cost of one billion (although now the debate is open, Highways England are inflating that figure). That is a difference of £750 million, minus the ongoing affects of air pollution the open road and loss of green space that will be inflicted on thousands of people. That is on top of cpo's, a decrease in house prices along the road and the inevitable increase in road accidents. 
But the scope here, is air pollution, how and why it should be addressed and my point is engineering something new that will significantly increase it is shows complete neglect for people by the government. What next, the return of asbestos roofing because the government can get a load of it cheap?', u'recommendation_count': u'2', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1537351887000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u'the government can get a load of it cheap', u'effect': u'what next'}], u'author_id': u'14284650', u'in_reply_to': u'120588819', u'id': u'120589719', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'VettelCrashes', u'text': u'I very much doubt anyone has five cars and then parks them on the street. The problem with on street parking was exacerbated by recent planning rules forbidding new builds with garages.
Much of the driving force behind the demonisation of the motor vehicle is jealousy. Public transport even at its best is crowded, uncomfortable, and inconvenient (often ceasing after midnight)
A car respresents your own personal space, where you arent subject to anyone else's BO, taste in music, conversation etc. This is why people like cars, and buses cannot compete.', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1537399986000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'100556257', u'in_reply_to': u'120575637', u'id': u'120617875', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'JonathanHughes', u'text': u'As much as it isn't a particularly pleasant attitude I tink the point they were making is true - most people really don't care', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1537351234000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'12031469', u'in_reply_to': u'120578299', u'id': u'120589243', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'JonathanHughes', u'text': u'Something smelling bad doesn't mean it is necessarily a health problem - whereas daily spraying of disinfectant is not a good idea', u'recommendation_count': u'2', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1537350889000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'12031469', u'in_reply_to': u'120583710', u'id': u'120589007', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'PhilosophicalSquid', u'text': u'What deeply a well articulated contribution and of course because you dont care, then nobody does.'nobody cares, because nobody thinks it'l happen to them... i dont. 'You are clearly the centre of existence.', u'recommendation_count': u'6', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1537318060000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u"nobody thinks it'l happen to them", u'effect': u"what deeply a well articulated contribution and of course because you do nt care then nobody does.'nobody cares"}, {u'cause': u'you do nt care', u'effect': u'what deeply a well articulated contribution and of course'}], u'author_id': u'17684224', u'in_reply_to': u'120574130', u'id': u'120578299', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'VettelCrashes', u'text': u'Your comment adequately demonstrates the rigorous thought processes empliyed by the renewable lobby.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1537398663000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'100556257', u'in_reply_to': u'120614272', u'id': u'120617484', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'JonathanHughes', u'text': u'There are laws for that - councils can set no idling regulation orders - the problem is putting them in and enforcing them is expensive (and most people react badly to any law that remotely impacts their ability to do whatever they want with their cars)', u'recommendation_count': u'3', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1537350758000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'12031469', u'in_reply_to': u'120584517', u'id': u'120588911', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'ChrisGordon1', u'text': u'I don't live in Lancashire anymore but how about this for an idea?. But the containers onto smaller ships and take them up to a new depot that would be built at the M6', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1537350634000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'16261177', u'in_reply_to': u'120588355', u'id': u'120588819', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'PhilosophicalSquid', u'text': u'And if you are so worried about obesity one would think you would welcome getting people on their feet and moving instead of stuck in traffic inhaling.This explains alot re rising dementia levelshttps://www.theguardian.com/environment/2018/sep/18/air-pollution-causes-jump-in-dementia-risk-study-suggests
Why oh why would you be King Canute.', u'recommendation_count': u'4', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1537317851000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'17684224', u'in_reply_to': u'120576343', u'id': u'120578251', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'PhilosophicalSquid', u'text': u'And many small cities/towns in the UK could easily do the same - and what youth unemployment has to do with it, Im not sure, but no links from you. And why are you so protective of polluting anyway?Are you that identified with your metal box?', u'recommendation_count': u'10', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1537317669000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'17684224', u'in_reply_to': u'120576343', u'id': u'120578213', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'TerryMcBurney', u'text': u'Air pollution is an urban problem due to the concentration of road traffic emissions and people affected by them. London has the worst incidences in the whole of the UK and is rightly the focus of attention. There is no reason for outsourcing production overseas for reasons of pollution since the mitigating technology exists if companies are willing to invest and we are prepared to pay the cost.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1537394467000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u'the concentration of road traffic emissions and people affected by them', u'effect': u'an urban problem'}], u'author_id': u'13800893', u'in_reply_to': u'120612901', u'id': u'120616329', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Shotcricket', u'text': u'So is nuclear & much more harmful to an entire population, still no population, no pollution, perhaps the explosive nuclear energy is the answer to cleaner air after all...eventually.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1537389878000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'16059320', u'in_reply_to': u'120598027', u'id': u'120614775', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'HurricaneFran', u'text': u'I couldn't agree more, if you have to live near one (or more) of those, it's a continual and violent attack on your breathing.', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1537350338000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'14006828', u'in_reply_to': u'120573158', u'id': u'120588587', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Stevencharles71', u'text': u'It could be. I believe the existing plan is the road through the country park, with a lorry park at the other end, because the lorries will, at times, be stacked up, waiting for their time to travel to and enter the port.
Rail only has a certain capacity though, not enough to move enough containers quickly enough, so whether investment in a dedicated three mile rail track, from the port to an area around Switch Island is worth it, I could not answer that, but it would certainly be something to look into.
The busiest port in the UK currently transports about 300,000 containers a year by rail, that would be about 10% of the projected number Liverpool will see by 2025.
The tunnel, in my view, could start within the port and so would be directly for port traffic, no traffic lights, no congestion, no public transport, no external pollution. Pollution would be treated as it is with other tunnels, including the Mersey Tunnels, which took ten years to contact, almost one hundred years ago. 
The tunnel would be about three miles, planning obstacles would surely be overcome quickly and considering the Channel tunnel took six years to construct in 1988 and is six or seven times longer, how quickly could the port tunnel be constructed, how quickly could Peel Holdings solve their problem and air pollution is permanently addressed, with the government preventing costs to the NHS year on year for ever. The port operates successfully, traffic flows, peole can breathe and the government has more money to spend in other departments. 
Short term thinking is the issue here and it is a disease.', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1537350040000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u'the lorries will at times be stacked up waiting for their time to travel to and enter the port', u'effect': u'the existing plan is the road through the country park with a lorry park at the other end'}], u'author_id': u'14284650', u'in_reply_to': u'120587781', u'id': u'120588355', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'KatieL', u'text': u'Well, it does depend on if you believe the official population numbers.
The Guardian is full of people saying the population hasn't risen drastically and there are no real jobs about and the population is living on poverty benefits.
Well; every weekday morning the roads are like car parks. The pavements actually ARE car parks. The trains are too full to get on. The few buses there are are full. There are cyclists everywhere. Everywhere you go, you queue for everything. Pedestrianised areas are rammed, shops are bursting at the seams. The schools are oversubscribed, the doctors is oversubscribed...
No -- I'm not even in London!
Where have all these people with all their demand for services come from? Looks to me like our population went up a lot.
(No, I voted Remain.)', u'recommendation_count': u'27', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1537295661000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'2676750', u'in_reply_to': u'120570819', u'id': u'120571332', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'ManyTruths', u'text': u'"That does not affect either levels of congestion nor vehicle emissions." u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'KatieL', u'text': u'Free public transport might not necessarily help.
I live near a station. Work is near a station. I drive to work. Why? The trains between the two are already packed to the point where people can't physically get on them.

Only unlike tube trains, they're an hour apart.

If Westminster will let them.', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1537384712000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'11797417', u'id': u'120613396', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'PhilosophicalSquid', u'text': u'Thats going to be oh so helpful given the timeline.I predict we will coopt others hard work and try and take credit for it, when everyone else has done all the graft and innovating, and its too late.It already is.One thing I hoped this brexit debacle might have taught this country, and I exclude Scotland and Ireland from our shame, is some form of humility.Fat chance among a certain demographic whose penile attributes are caught up with their embarrassing flag waving.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1537384024000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'17684224', u'in_reply_to': u'120609087', u'id': u'120613186', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Stevencharles71', u'text': u'Consider the situation in Liverpool. The port, owned by Peel Holdings, has seen a £400 million investment to construct a deep water terminal, which will enable the port to welcome the largest container ships in the world and increase capacity by 500%.
The port now has the problem of transporting millions more containers every year between the port and the motorway. Currently, the hgvs are travelling along a very tight dual carriage way (A5036) fifteen foot from houses on both sides and past a handful of schools and the route is officially one of the most congested in England.
So the people in that area and the port need a solution. The solution, according to Highways England/ The government, is not a tunnel from the port to the motorway, specifically for the millions of hgvs that would use it each year, it is to build an open road through a country park, increasing air pollution at a time when every developed country realises the extent of the problem, even if it is failing to properly address it or address it at all. 
I think it is one thing looking at existing roads and areas which are heavily polluted and wondering how they can be improved, but to actually deliberately create a new one in 2018 should be deemed a criminal act, given all the evidence of the affects of air pollution we are now seeing almost daily, effects which will directly cost the NHS in all sorts of ways, including social care, on an ongoing basis. 
The Mersey Gateway, recently opened, has a £7 each way toll for hgvs. How long would it take for a tunnel from the port to the motorway to pay for itself, without considering the costs to the NHS of an open road from potential accidents to the affects of air pollution.
The worst thing about this is Labour councillors and mp's, in a Labour constituency, voted for the expansion to the port, without access in place to manage the significant increase in traffic it would bring. The Tories can be blamed for providing Highways England with a budget large enough only for an external road, but, unfortunately, the expansion, without environmentally friendly access, would never have happened, if Labour councillors and mps had not given it the green light. 
I am not blaming Peel Holdings whose interest is only within the port, or even Highways England, who are working to a budget set by the government. I am blaming the government directly, for choosing to build an external road for dock traffic, at a time when any government should be doing anything but.', u'recommendation_count': u'4', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1537348564000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'14284650', u'id': u'120587276', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'erenata', u'text': u'It matters not one iota where it comes from or what it is..cities are mucky places.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1537348510000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'14430328', u'in_reply_to': u'120579714', u'id': u'120587245', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Staf0048', u'text': u'Just do what America did back in the 70's, move all the dirty manufacturering overseas.

In terms of lobbying and political clout it's clear where the power lies! Charging polluting vehicles is important with the aim of removing them entirely in the medium term, but a more comprehensive approach is needed driven by central government. Big increases in pedestrian and cycle routes, cleaner and cheaper public transport, and a big investment in electric vehicle technology and charging points. We could have charging points running all day driven by solar for commuter vehicles, electric vans and minibuses and delivery vehicles charged at night by off peak renewable energy. Reshape power generation and supply around renewable energy for vehicles in urban settings, then bring forward the full abolition of petrol and diesel vehicles. Big investment but good for health and productivity and good for the planet.', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1537343378000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'11640473', u'id': u'120583871', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'AlfP', u'text': u'If the truth must be told; the stench, not just mere odious smell, from drainages and sewers in London and perhaps many other cities across the country is a very serious health hazard.

Local Authorities used to spray streets with disinfectants every night to treat, neutralise and clear drainages and sewers of any unpleasant stench, etc. They do not do these anymore. London Assembly is not helping either but makes noises around issues. Do not scapegoat motor vehicle exhausts.

Multiple car ownership should be banned
BQENDOwning multiple cars makes absolutely no difference. No matter how many you own, you can only drive one at a time.
That does not affect either levels of congestion nor vehicle emissions.', u'recommendation_count': u'6', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1537308667000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'4109931', u'in_reply_to': u'120572426', u'id': u'120575889', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'graun', u'text': u'This bears all the hallmarks of media-driven moral panic. There is a government agency called the National Atmospheric Emissions Inventory. They analyse the causes and quantity of particle emissions in the UK.They tell us that since 1990 particle emissions have decreased by 55%. So why all these media articles about pollution now, when it is lower than it has been for nearly 30 years?
Vehicle emissions over that time have remained pretty constant and make up just over 10% of all particle emissions in the country. That is despite the number of miles driven rising by 60% over that time. Cars, lorries and buses are doing more miles, but each one is much cleaner than it used to be. The result is that car emissions have not changed.All that has changed is media hysteria.
As for the rest, the almost complete closure of coal-fired power stations has had a massive effect on reducing particulates in the atmosphere. Industrial processes have also cleaned up - nearly halving their emissions.
The only thing that has increased is the smoke from wood burning stoves. We are told that now creates 3 times more pollution than cars. Even worse is that this is mainly in towns and cities and that wood smoke contains many more carcinogens than vehicle exhaust does.
If we want to clean up our cities and have better air quality, banging on about cars and diesels won't do it. Target the trendy middle classes with wood burners. They are the people who each push out more pollution in an hour than a lorry does in three.', u'recommendation_count': u'17', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1537308269000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'4109931', u'id': u'120575753', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Veronica22b', u'text': u'It is strange that in a time when we pretty much universally accept that the pollution from petrol and diesel cars is something that is incredibly bad for us (and, although more arguably for many) the planet, as a society we still allow and in many cases promote the production and purchase of cars with far larger and more powerful engines than we actually need; cars that spew out many times more pollutants than is necessary to get us to work, to the shops, or get the kids to school. Simply to pander to the egos of those either foolish enough to believe it makes them more admired, or so lacking in imagination as to need it to have excitement in their lives. Bizarrely, the latter will overwhelmingly not have the guts to go motor racing instead of using the streets for their thrills. There are plenty of cars that will do over 50mpg on petrol, and far more on diesel if that's your preference. As for belief that it's ok to pollute as long as you pay an additional tax - absolute madness.', u'recommendation_count': u'3', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1537361960000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'17433782', u'id': u'120598450', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Harvestingkarma', u'text': u'The carpeting in the home is toxic as it holds all kind of miniscule irritants, particles of dirt, microbe and the stuff the carpet is made from. Go back to timber flooring and rugs that can be taken outside and given a good beating as used to always be the case.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1537361571000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'16314139', u'in_reply_to': u'120589894', u'id': u'120598116', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'formerlefty', u'text': u'BQSTART
Until the 19th century internal combustion engine is consigned to history we're going to have to suck it up.
BQEND
Why? No reason why there need to be large numbers of private motorised vehicles, yet alone diesel vehicles, in the centre of urban areas. You suck it up if you like, I'm tired of being used as a human filter for motorists' filth (had enough of that as a child in London absorbing all their lead - the average Londoner back then had several times what is now the legal maximum level of lead in thier bloodstream, all so motorists could save money). 
 A large proportion of car journeys in urban areas are unnecessary, and there are far too many taxis. Stop subsiidising car use, charge motorists the true cost of their behaviour, and the pollution will be reduced.', u'recommendation_count': u'5', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1537341976000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'2829513', u'in_reply_to': u'120582698', u'id': u'120583186', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'ms10', u'text': u'In the meantime Westminster City Council happily blocks any attempts to improve air quality in the borough. description: Editorial: As evidence about the harmful effects of pollution mounts, mayors need to take action to reduce emissions and improve health
og_fields.og:description: Editorial: As evidence about the harmful effects of pollution mounts, mayors need to take action to reduce emissions and improve health
og_fields.og:title: The Guardian view on clean air zones: cities must be bold | Editorial
text:
The slogan “Think global, act local”, popular among environmentalists since the 1970s, is apt when applied to the politics of air. While pollution by greenhouse gases, chiefly CO2, requires international action, some emissions can be tackled much closer to home. Evidence about the health impact of the gases and particles produced by road traffic, industry and open fires has developed rapidly since the 1990s. In cities, many of which have experienced rapid growth in traffic, air quality has become a pressing issue.
Across the EU, legal limits are regularly breached, and the UK, France and Germany are among six countries facing large fines. Until Michael Gove publishes his environment bill there remains uncertainty over the teeth the watchdog will have when it comes to enforcing the rules after Brexit. But it is not clear whether the genie of public anxiety about toxic air can be pushed back into the bottle. This week saw reports about new research into the amount of particulate matter breathed by children at London schools, and pollutants found in mothers’ placentas. Last month it was revealed that Chinese researchers have linked high levels of air pollution to reduced intelligence.
New clean air zones in London and Birmingham, including charges for the most polluting vehicles, start their rollout next year (two other cities, Southampton and Derby, have been ticked off by the government for missing a deadline for proposals). Such schemes represent a milestone in efforts to limit nitrogen oxide pollution from diesel vehicles after the still-unfolding emissions-cheating scandal. This weekend will see the closure of 50 roads for the capital’s first “car-free day”, an initiative campaigners hope will soon be scaled up to match more ambitious schemes in cities including Brussels and Paris.
What happens next depends on public opinion as well as government. Parents are increasingly worried about the health of their children. Rosamund Kissi-Debrah, who believes air pollution killed her daughter Ella, wants to argue the case in a new inquest. On the other side of the argument are those concerned about the impact of charges. In Birmingham, these include businesses supplying parts to the local automotive industry. In London, Westminster city council has opposed schemes it says penalise its residents, and last week inflicted a defeat on the mayor in the high court. No politician is likely to forget the saga of the London congestion zone’s western extension, which lasted only a year before being scrapped.
The situation is complicated because vehicle emissions and air pollution, while closely linked to congestion, are not the same thing. Urban transport is a political question and dirty air is not the only reason many people would like to see traffic reduced. Others include road safety, noise, and the belief that public transport, bicycles and pedestrians should take priority over private cars – even electric ones. On the other side, many people are attached to their cars and see driving as their right and an economic necessity.
Were it not for the obstructive policies pursued by Boris Johnson, London would be further ahead than it is. Birmingham and Manchester are catching up. The obesity crisis as well as air pollution and congestion means the direction of travel – towards healthier and more active lifestyles, and less traffic – should be clear. Per-mile road pricing was looked at by Mr Khan last year and remains under review. Whether by this route or another, cities and their leaders must find a way through.

From the MIT tropical cyclone expert Kerry Emanuel.
BQSTART
Here I define an index of the potential destructiveness of hurricanes based on the total dissipation of power, integrated over the lifetime of the cyclone, and show that this index has increased markedly since the mid-1970s. This trend is due to both longer storm lifetimes and greater storm intensities. 
I find that the record of net hurricane power dissipation is highly correlated with tropical sea surface temperature, reflecting well-documented climate signals, including multi-decadal oscillations in the North Atlantic and North Pacific, and global warming. 
My results suggest that future warming may lead to an upward trend in tropical cyclone destructive potential, and—taking into account an increasing coastal population—a substantial increase in hurricane-related losses in the twenty-first century.
BQEND

BQSTART

The lines on this graph of ice sheet mass loss curve downwards, indicating acceleration. http://www.columbia.edu/~mhs119/IceSheet/IceMass.png
At the recent acceleration rate of ice sheet mass loss of around 44 Gt/yr2, reported by Eric Rignot last year, (each year an extra 44Gt move into the ocean) we get 78cm of SLR from the ice sheets alone by 2100. Thermal expansion and mountain glaciers add another 20-30cm which brings us up to ~1m.
Here's a graph of post glacial sea level rise, showing both how stable the ice sheets have been for 6000 years and what they can do when they “let go”. During Meltwater Pulse 1A sea level rose 4m per century for four centuries. There were larger ice sheets then, but that rate indicates that the ice sheets can do dramatic things when they retreat. 
When the 120km wide Thwaites Glacier in West Antarctica backs up off its stabilizing sill into a 2.5km deep hole in the ocean, it’s going to try to make marine-terminating ice cliffs over 1000m high when it’s been observed at Jakobshavn Glacier in Greenland that ice cliffs over 100m in height collapse. It is a chaotic system. We learn about it all the time. The computer simulations used to predict economic events are improving. But the long-term prediction of the economy is still impossible."
In the last year of the millennium drought as my city faced the prospect of running out of water, I watched as, year after year, the US government ran budget deficit after budget deficit. At this time of year as a weak El Nino turned into a weak La Nina my young friend who was state treasurer was in a very serious meeting on a Sunday about planning for a possible financial crisis when three supercells collided over our suburbs producing 200 kph winds. He was unaware of the storm but well aware of the possible consequences of US fiscal policy for the world.
A change from El Nino to La Nina increases the chance of supercell storms and continual budget deficits without income generation increases the chance of a financial crisis. What's hard to predict is when the storm comes or when the financial crisis hits. Here we had enough sense to prepare for the change in the economic climate, so that when the financial storm crossed the Pacific we were as ready for that as we were for that supercell collision.', u'recommendation_count': u'5', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1537618888000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'12483673', u'in_reply_to': u'120693467', u'id': u'120713446', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'ElephantofTruth', u'text': u'Good post Walsunda.', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1537618822000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'4154310', u'in_reply_to': u'120712422', u'id': u'120713403', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'quokkaZ', u'text': u'BQSTART

Walsunda. Microprocessors are better. We are learning more about climate all the time. This does not mean climate has evolved from a Chaotic System to a non-Chaotic system."
Although ultimately climate can will kill a weather forecast, this does not necessarily prevent long term prediction of the climate - the statistics of weather averaged over suitable time and perhaps space scales. The calculation of climate variables (that is long term averages) is much easier than weather forecasting, since weather is ruled by vagaries of stochastic fluctuations, while climate is not.
We can demonstrate this sort of climate response clearly in the Lorenz model, or any more complex climate model. Perturbing the initial conditions gives a completely different trajectory (weather), but this averages out over time, and the statistics of different long-term runs are indistinguishable. However a steady perturbation to the system can generate a significant change to the long-term statistics. This disproves the common but misguided claim that chaotic weather prevents meaningful climate prediction. In fact, all climate models do predict that the change in globally-averaged steady state temperature, at least, is almost exactly proportional to the change in the net radiative forcing, indicating a near-linear response of the climate, at least on the broadest scales. 
 At the centre of chaos theory is the fascinating idea that order and chaos are not always diametrically opposed. Chaotic systems are an intimate mix of the two. From the outside they display unpredictable and chaotic behaviour, but expose the inner workings and you discover a perfectly deterministic set of equations working like clockwork.
Some systems flip this premise around, with orderly effects emerging out of turbulent and chaotic causes. With respect to temperature the climate system is such a system.', u'recommendation_count': u'7', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1537617411000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'12483673', u'in_reply_to': u'120693467', u'id': u'120712422', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'ID1925730', u'text': u'Its that or start actually discussing openly the 'negative growth' scenarios that big oil needs to engage with now. description: Benjamin Franta: Newly found documents from the 1980s show that fossil fuel companies privately predicted the global damage that would be caused by their products.
og_fields.og:description: Benjamin Franta: Newly found documents from the 1980s show that fossil fuel companies privately predicted the global damage that would be caused by their products.
og_fields.og:title: Shell and Exxon's secret 1980s climate change warnings | Benjamin Franta
text:
One day in 1961, an American economist named Daniel Ellsberg stumbled across a piece of paper with apocalyptic implications. Ellsberg, who was advising the US government on its secret nuclear war plans, had discovered a document that contained an official estimate of the death toll in a preemptive “first strike” on China and the Soviet Union: 300 million in those countries, and double that globally.
Ellsberg was troubled that such a plan existed; years later, he tried to leak the details of nuclear annihilation to the public. Although his attempt failed, Ellsberg would become famous instead for leaking what came to be known as the Pentagon Papers – the US government’s secret history of its military intervention in Vietnam.
America’s amoral military planning during the Cold War echoes the hubris exhibited by another cast of characters gambling with the fate of humanity. Recently, secret documents have been unearthed detailing what the energy industry knew about the links between their products and global warming. But, unlike the government’s nuclear plans, what the industry detailed was put into action.
In the 1980s, oil companies like Exxon and Shell carried out internal assessments of the carbon dioxide released by fossil fuels, and forecast the planetary consequences of these emissions. In 1982, for example, Exxon predicted that by about 2060, CO2 levels would reach around 560 parts per million – double the preindustrial level – and that this would push the planet’s average temperatures up by about 2°C over then-current levels (and even more compared to pre-industrial levels).
Later that decade, in 1988, an internal report by Shell projected similar effects but also found that CO2 could double even earlier, by 2030. Privately, these companies did not dispute the links between their products, global warming, and ecological calamity. On the contrary, their research confirmed the connections.
Shell’s assessment foresaw a one-meter sea-level rise, and noted that warming could also fuel disintegration of the West Antarctic Ice Sheet, resulting in a worldwide rise in sea level of “five to six meters.” That would be enough to inundate entire low-lying countries.
Shell’s analysts also warned of the “disappearance of specific ecosystems or habitat destruction,” predicted an increase in “runoff, destructive floods, and inundation of low-lying farmland,” and said that “new sources of freshwater would be required” to compensate for changes in precipitation. Global changes in air temperature would also “drastically change the way people live and work.” All told, Shell concluded, “the changes may be the greatest in recorded history.”
For its part, Exxon warned of “potentially catastrophic events that must be considered.” Like Shell’s experts, Exxon’s scientists predicted devastating sea-level rise, and warned that the American Midwest and other parts of the world could become desert-like. Looking on the bright side, the company expressed its confidence that “this problem is not as significant to mankind as a nuclear holocaust or world famine.”
The documents make for frightening reading. And the effect is all the more chilling in view of the oil giants’ refusal to warn the public about the damage that their own researchers predicted. Shell’s report, marked “confidential,” was first disclosed by a Dutch news organization earlier this year. Exxon’s study was not intended for external distribution, either; it was leaked in 2015.
Nor did the companies ever take responsibility for their products. In Shell’s study, the firm argued that the “main burden” of addressing climate change rests not with the energy industry, but with governments and consumers. That argument might have made sense if oil executives, including those from Exxon and Shell, had not later lied about climate change and actively prevented governments from enacting clean-energy policies.
Although the details of global warming were foreign to most people in the 1980s, among the few who had a better idea than most were the companies contributing the most to it. Despite scientific uncertainties, the bottom line was this: oil firms recognized that their products added CO2 to the atmosphere, understood that this would lead to warming, and calculated the likely consequences. And then they chose to accept those risks on our behalf, at our expense, and without our knowledge.
The catastrophic nuclear war plans that Ellsberg saw in the 1960s were a Sword of Damocles that fortunately never fell. But the oil industry’s secret climate change predictions are becoming reality, and not by accident. Fossil-fuel producers willfully drove us toward the grim future they feared by promoting their products, lying about the effects, and aggressively defending their share of the energy market.
As the world warms, the building blocks of our planet – its ice sheets, forests, and atmospheric and ocean currents – are being altered beyond repair. Who has the right to foresee such damage and then choose to fulfill the prophecy? Although war planners and fossil-fuel companies had the arrogance to decide what level of devastation was appropriate for humanity, only Big Oil had the temerity to follow through. That, of course, is one time too many.
Benjamin Franta, a former research fellow at the Belfer Center for Science and International Affairs at the Harvard Kennedy School of Government, is a doctoral candidate at Stanford University, where his research focuses on the history of climate science and politics.
An earlier version of this piece, entitled “Global Warming’s Paper Trail”, was published on Sept. 12, 2018 by Project Syndicate.

[{u'author': u'Erik Frederiksen', u'text': u'It seems like this article could have been more balanced, given the posts below by mrm and tt which showed some perspectives which the article, and headline, failed to present.

The people talking to the Observer think that this process has gone too far and removed or watered down things that shouldn't have been, others on the winning side of that discussion are predictably defending their decision.
Fortunately, "Drafts & comments will be publicly available so these claims will be testable" although any post-publication analysis will inevitably have less impact than the initial headlines which is presumably why the side that thinks there has been watering down is trying to get those headlines in first.
Either way this looks to be a report on one side of a subjective argument more than an objective claim of malfeasance.', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1537920569000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'3491752', u'in_reply_to': u'120831872', u'id': u'120852833', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Isaboy', u'text': u'It’s clear where your affiliation applies.

There is no excuse.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1537918489000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'4062924', u'in_reply_to': u'120829140', u'id': u'120852295', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'TuwitTuwit', u'text': u'Interesting link. Erik does what Erik does because of what happens in his own bit of the physical world. It affects his views and opinions.
Try sticking the names into a web search and see which individual has greater visibility on the subject of climate change. Erik is decidedly local to BTL comments. Anthony, however...', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1537913818000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'18111377', u'in_reply_to': u'120826122', u'id': u'120850743', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'rockyrex', u'text': u'I agree with you (for once) - citing non-scientific sources such as Hollywood movies is far from wise.
However, as we might be running out of time to comment on this article, I'll share something with you.
Professor Russell Coope was the first to discover abrupt climate change events in the geological record of the 'ice age', while doing research for his Ph.D back in the 1950s.
Coope - who was my palaeontology lecturer long ago - made his discovery entirely by accident, while researching fossil beetle assemblages in 'ice age' sedimentary successions.
He ended up spending decades applying this technique to more and more examples of similar sedimentary successions - the process works because a beetle wing-case is usually sufficient to identify a species, and the species have not changed much in a long time.
Any given collection of species taken together indicates a very precise temperature.
His discovery tells us that the Earth's climates are not necessarily stable.
These rapid climate events were confirmed a few decades later by ice cores from the Greenland ice sheet..... the events he discovered had a number of natural causes.
Not long before he died in 2011, he said that people are messing with a trigger that causes climate change, and the consequences are likely to be 'ferocious'.
'Ferocious' is a difficult word to forget.
We are probably not facing very rapid changes, but that doesn't mean the outcome is any less serious.
"The climatic impacts of releasing fossil fuel CO2 to the atmosphere will last longer than Stonehenge.........Longer than time capsules, longer than nuclear waste, far longer than the age of human civilization so far."
From this interesting article:
http://www.nature.com/climate/2008/0812/full/climate.2008.122.html', u'recommendation_count': u'5', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1537910293000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u'a beetle wing case is usually sufficient to identify a species and the species have not changed much in a long time', u'effect': u'he ended up spending decades applying this technique to more and more examples of similar sedimentary successions the process works'}, {u'cause': u'that', u'effect': u'climate change'}], u'author_id': u'2923581', u'in_reply_to': u'120798942', u'id': u'120848994', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'rockyrex', u'text': u'Always best to check with the original people involved.
A pity the author (and Guardian staff) didn't do that in this case.', u'recommendation_count': u'4', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1537909891000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'2923581', u'in_reply_to': u'120831872', u'id': u'120848846', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'rockyrex', u'text': u'The period you are interested in, from the end of the 20th century, was a time when there was a big expansion of burning of poor quality coal in China and India, which produced lots of aerosols such as sulphates.
This paper:
"Reconciling anthropogenic climate change with observed temperature 1998–2008" - Kaufman et al, 2011
http://www.pnas.org/content/108/29/11790.abstract
BQSTART
rapid growth in short-lived sulfur emissions partially offsets rising greenhouse gas concentrations
BQEND
is worth a look.
This is a short-term effect, and there was a similar short-lived phase around the mid-20th century when there was a big expansion of burning of poor quality coal, which produced lots of aerosols such as sulphates - which temporarily produced a phenomenon called 'global dimming'.
This masked the effect of CO2 for a few decades.
As a result, global average temperatures were largely stable from 1940 to 1975.
To date, all 17 years of the 21st century rank among the 18 warmest on record (adding 1998 makes up the full 18.)
The top 5 years (from NOAA) are - 5th, 2010 ....... 4th, 2014 .... 3rd, 2017 ...... 2nd, 2015 .... 1st, 2016.
Climate sensitivity looks at the long-range.
Results of studies of the geological record tend to centre on around 3 for climate sensitivity.
I suggest you look at this -
"Emergent constraint on equilibrium climate sensitivity from global temperature variability" - Cox et al, 2018
https://www.nature.com/articles/nature25450

BQSTART
2.2-3.4C, 2.8C with 66% confidence limits
BQEND
So doubling CO2 from around 270 ppm (the pre-industrial value) to around 540 ppm would raise average global temperatures by around 2.8 C deg.
That's going to have some significant effects - and remember - it's an average.
For some places the rise will be more (and for some, yes, it will be less)
Around 1800 AD CO2 was at about 280 ppm.
It began to rise fairly slowly as the Industrial Revolution developed.
By 1900, it was at around 300 ppm, about 20 ppm above the level in 1800.
By 1950 CO2 was at about 310 ppm.
Now it's over 400 ppm.
So a doubling from 280 ppm would take it to 560 ppm.
Currently the rise is over 20 ppm per decade, so around 560 ppm later this century is entirely possible if no significant action is taken.

"The past three years have seen the return of widespread rainfall deficiencies across southern and eastern Australia (Figure 1). Below average rainfall across large parts of Australia since the end of the 2010 and 2011 La Nina events, and the failure of the northern wet season over much of inland Queensland over the past three years have contributed to these deficiencies (see the latest issue of the Bureau's Drought Statement for more information."
"These deficiencies re-emerge against a background of significant longer term rainfall decline over southern Australia which has persisted for decades. The southwest of Western Australia has experienced a 10 to 20 percent drop in winter rainfall since around 1970 - that has been expressed as a step-change or series of step-changes, rather than a gradual decline. This period also includes the absence of high-rainfall years that were common prior to that period. The southeast of the continent has experienced a similar decline in late autumn and early winter rain since around the 1990s (see State of the Climate for 2014 for more information). These rainfall changes have been accompanied by much larger reductions in streamflow particularly in the south west."

However, if one read that Wikipedia article and the supporting peer reviewed papers published in proper scientific, one finds they do not support what you say about Holocene climate optimum and the radiation and diversification of avian dinosaurs and mammals following the extinction of the non-avian dinosaurs.
"The entry in Wikipedia drives the point home re the point of view of many researchers that anything humanity does to alter nature is automatically bad."
As someone who has worked on Pleistocene and Holocene mammals, Cretaceous tetrapods and Permian brachiopods, I assure you it doesn't do that at all, because researchers base there knowledge of what has happened in the evidence of the geological record which shows that the Holocene climate optimum occurred 66 million years after the extinction of non-avian dinosaurs, that it wasn't a case of global warming and that global temperatures were close to those of the present day but because the warming was due to Northern Hemisphere high latitude summer insolation, it was concentrated in the higher latitudes of that hemisphere and occurred during summer.
"Apparently it earned that title" of Holocene climate optimum ", because the data, information in it on which it was appraised in isolation and judged on its own merits."
The term Holocene climate optimum was used in response to evidence a warmer climate in the high latitude parts of Europe. As someone who has visited that region in winter I can understand why a warmer climate would be regarded as optimal - but then I do come from the subtropics.  "On its merits the world during the Holocene climate optimum was a lush, life filled place."
As the Wikipedia article you referred to explains the Holocene climate optimum warming was restricted to the polar regions and northwest Europe while Southern Europe, The Tropics and the Southern Hemisphere were cooler.
 There is evidence of enhancement of the northern monsoon in northern Australia and a more more humid phase early to mid Holocene of the Sahara. However in the record of activity of the northern monsoon in Australia's Lake Eyre, there is also also evidence of three stages of even greater lushness and greater northern monsoon activity during the last glacial period. The early- to mid-Holocene peak in summer insolation at 20 degrees North due to the 20,000 year cycle in orbital precession caused a time of humid climate in the Sahara.
Magee et al (2004) "Continuous 150 k.y. monsoon record from Lake Eyre Australia: Insolation-forcing implications and unexpected Holocene failure" Geology Volume 32 Number 10 pp 885-888
deMenocal et al (2012) "Green Sahara Humid Periods Paced by Earth's Orbital Changes " https://www.nature.com/scitable/knowledge/library/green-sahara-african-humid-period-paced-by-82884405
The Northern Hemisphere high latitude peak in summer insolation that led to deglaciation between 19,000 and 9,000 years ago and in combination with 40% increase in atmospheric CO2 over those 10,000 years the early- to mid-holocene climate optimum, is a product of orbital eccentricty rather than precession. " It begs the question why a world warmed by our activities that will sport the same worldwide climate is supposed to be such a nightmare." 
As the world of the Holocene climate optimum was not warmed by human activities and global greenhouse warming, it did not sport the same climate as would one warmed by our activities. I don't know about your nightmares but at this stage of my life I don't have such dreams. However, I do know that a number of extreme climate events have increased in frequency as the world has warmed globally since the middle of the last century. I also know that people from cool climates when confronted with such events in the tropical and subtropical regions of the world can find them nightmarish. the 2017 global temperature remains stubbornly high, well above the trend line (Fig. 1), despite cooler than average temperature in the tropical Pacific Niño 3.4 region (Fig. 5), which usually provides an indication of the tropical Pacific effect on global temperature7. 
Conceivably this continued temperature excursion above the trend line is not a statistical fluke, but rather is associated with climate forcings and/or feedbacks. The growth rate of greenhouse gas climate forcing has accelerated in the past decade.3 There is also concern that polar climate feedbacks may accelerate.8
Therefore, temperature change during even the next few years is of interest, to determine whether a significant excursion above the trend line is underway.

Abstract
BQSTART
I suggest that a 'scientific reticence' is inhibiting the communication of a threat of a potentially large sea level rise. Delay is dangerous because of system inertias that could create a situation with future sea level changes out of our control. I argue for calling together a panel of scientific leaders to hear evidence and issue a prompt plain-written report on current understanding of the sea level change issue.
BQEND

In 1981 Hansen warned that multimeter sea level rise was possible within 100 years and the more we learn about the ice sheets the closer to his projections modern glaciology is approaching.', u'recommendation_count': u'3', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1537845505000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u'system inertias that could create a situation with future sea level changes out of our control', u'effect': u'delay is dangerous'}], u'author_id': u'15131989', u'in_reply_to': u'120812415', u'id': u'120812659', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Erik Frederiksen', u'text': u'From a 2014 article by the MIT atmospheric physicist Kerry Emanuel titled Tail Risk vs Alarmism
BQSTART
More or less in agreement with the most recent IPCC report, the most probable “middle” of the distribution runs from about 1.5 oC to about 4.5oC , while there is a roughly 5% probability of temperature increases being less than about 1.8 oC and more than about 4.6 oC. But, given the corresponding distributions of rainfall, storms, sea level rise, etc., the 5% high-end may be so consequential, in terms of outcome, as to be justifiably called catastrophic. It is vitally important that we convey this tail risk as well as the most probable outcomes. 
But there are strong cultural biases running against any discussion of this kind of tail risk, at least in the realm of climate science. The legitimate fear that the public will interpret any discussion whatsoever of tail risk as a deliberate attempt to scare people into action, or to achieve some other ulterior or nefarious goal, is enough to make almost all scientists shy away from any talk of tail risk and stick to the safe high ground of the middle of the probability distribution. The accusation of “alarmism” is quite effective in making scientists skittish in conveying tail risk, and talking about the tail of the distribution is a sure recipe to be so labelled.
BQEND
http://climatechangenationalforum.org/tail-risk-vs-alarmism/

A good 140 years...', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1537843205000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'17722198', u'in_reply_to': u'120798598', u'id': u'120812384', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Erik Frederiksen', u'text': u'Regarding that first meter of SLR, at the current acceleration of ice sheet mass loss of 44 GT/y2 reported last year by Eric Rignot we get 78cm from the ice sheets alone by 2100.
Throw in another 20-30cm for thermal expansion and mountain glaciers and that’s ~1m that we are already on pace for by 2100.

(It’s retreated 14km over a recent 19 year period in the main flow)', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1537841120000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'15131989', u'in_reply_to': u'120811826', u'id': u'120812154', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Walsunda', u'text': u'"After the extinction of non-avian dinosaurs, the Earth experienced an epic period of global warming." Because this sentence immediately follows an imprecisely erroneous one about the Holocene Climate Optimum 66 million years after the extinction of the non-avian dinosaurs, you seem to be talking about warming event, which (see above) was not a global warming event, most certainly quite some time after that extinction event.
However, I'll give you the benefit of the doubt and assume that you are talking about the Palaeocene Eocene Thermal Maximum or PETM which occurred 10 million years after the extinction of the non-avian dinosaurs, giving the surviving avian dinosaurs and mammals plenty of time to evolve into a wide variety of lineages.
"If a warmer world were so detrimental to life, we'd have seen proof in geological records of that period. Instead we see a runaway diversification of life as mammals, birds and life that survived the extinction event."
We see a diversification of the smaller possibly burrowing insectivorous animals that survived the end-Cretaceous extinction event. This diversification and evolutionary radiation occurred in the 10 million years between the extinction event and the start of the PETM which lasted for 200,000 years, then continued after it.', u'recommendation_count': u'2', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1537841056000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'12483673', u'in_reply_to': u'120740174', u'id': u'120812149', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Erik Frederiksen', u'text': u'The IPCC not only gives numbers for sea level rise, but also the uncertainties.
For example in 2007 they supplied a table with numbers for sea level rise. But there was a notation on the table SPM-3 which read “model-based range excluding future rapid dynamical changes in ice sheet flow”.
Because they didn’t know what the ice sheets will do; we still don’t, although we’ve observed recent accelerating mass loss.
Richard Alley mentioned that some analyses floated around which ignored that notation, and that that may have led to some ill-founded complacency about future sea level rise.', u'recommendation_count': u'3', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1537838508000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u'that', u'effect': u'some ill founded complacency about future sea level rise'}], u'author_id': u'15131989', u'in_reply_to': u'120811163', u'id': u'120811835', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'DennisHorne', u'text': u'It's not the sea level rise in metres that is uncertain, it's the timescale. In living with South Est Asian fishing people I realised that people people from developing countries are not different to us whose dominant cultural background is from Europe despite having lived in the East for around 150 years. I also realised how only a small increase in wealth both public and private could achieve so much in such countries.
A year or two later I found myself working with some of the first Chinese scientists to be allowed to leave their country to bring their subject knowledge and practice up to world standard. They went back and underpinned the Chinese industrial revolution buying their first TV set and fridge on their way home through Hong Kong. Over good Chinese food and few beers, we didn't just discuss shop.
For happiness though and a good life consumption of goods for their own sake brings diminishing rewards. Our small house surrounded by rainforest trees is sufficient. Our parents were happy to have achieved ownership of such a house and to have brought up children who made their way in this world as are we. People in the developing world are no different to us in that respect.', u'recommendation_count': u'2', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1537835813000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'12483673', u'in_reply_to': u'120798111', u'id': u'120811416', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'John Brookes', u'text': u'The IPCC has a policy of not being alarmist. If the IPCC comes out and says that sea levels will rise by 3m in the next 80 years, they will be painted as alarmist, and the conservatives will feel entirely justified in ignoring them. description: ‘True risks’ of warming played down to placate fossil-fuel nations
headline: l
og_fields.og:description: ‘True risks’ of warming played down to placate fossil-fuel nations
og_fields.og:title: Climate study ‘pulls punches’ to keep polluters on board
text:
Warnings about the dangers of global warming are being watered down in the final version of a key climate report for a major international meeting next month, according to reviewers who have studied earlier versions of the report and its summary.
They say scientists working on the final draft of the summary are censoring their own warnings and “pulling their punches” to make policy recommendations seem more palatable to countries – such as the US, Saudi Arabia and Australia – that are reluctant to cut fossil-fuel emissions, a key cause of global warming. “Downplaying the worst impacts of climate change has led the scientific authors to omit crucial information from the summary for policymakers,” said one reviewer, Bob Ward, policy director at the Grantham Research Institute on Climate Change and the Environment.
“However, if governments do not recognise the full scale and urgency of the risks, they may underestimate how critical it is to meet the goal of the Paris agreement on climate change. And that could have very serious knock-on effects in the battle to limit the impact of global warming.”
The Special Report on Global Warming of 1.5C and its summary for policymakers were commissioned by governments following the UN meeting in Paris in 2015, when it was agreed to act to limit increases in global average temperature to less than 2C above pre-industrial levels and to try keep that increase nearer to 1.5C.
The report – to be presented at a meeting in Korea in early October – will make clear that allowing temperatures to rise by 2C will have devastating consequences, including rising sea levels, spreading deserts, loss of natural habitats and species, dwindling ice-caps and increases in the number of devastating storms.
However, it is the report’s summary for policymakers that is causing concern. This is the document politicians will use as a key climate guide when making changes to legislation. Reviewers of earlier drafts say it is being altered to make the dangers of climate change seem less alarming. As a result, they say,, policymakers could seriously underestimate the risks of global warming. Cuts made to the final draft of the summary include:
• Any mention that temperature rises of above 1.5C could lead to increased migrations and conflict;
• All discussion of the danger of the Gulf Stream being disrupted by cold water flowing from the Arctic where more and more sea-ice is melting;
• Warnings about the dangers that 1.5–2C temperature rises could trigger irreversible loss of the Greenland ice sheet and raise sea levels by 1–2 metres over the next two centuries.
Other cuts from the summary include the sentence: “Poverty and disadvantage have increased with recent warming (about 1C) and are expected to increase in many populations as average global temperatures increase from 1C to 1.5C and beyond.” 
The original summary also stated “at 2C warming, there is a potential for significant population displacement concentrated in the tropics”. Again this is not mentioned in the report for policymakers. “The scientists who produce reports like these try to summarise the latest knowledge, but they have a reputation for being conservative about the worst risks of climate change,” Ward said. “This time they have outdone themselves in pulling their punches, however.”
An IPCC spokesman said member governments would work to ensure the summary for policymakers was consistent with the findings in the main report. “They may change the wording of text there to clarify, remove material from the summary for policymakers, or bring material from the main report that was not there at the start of the session. Any text in the summary for policymakers … is based on the assessment in the main report. Even if it is removed from the summary for policymakers, the finding it is based on remains in the main report.”

article_tags: [Climate change, Environment]
description: Heatwaves, hurricanes and floods will make some places in the US inhospitable
og_fields.og:description: Heatwaves, hurricanes and floods will make some places in the US inhospitable
og_fields.og:title: Where should you move to save yourself from climate change?
text:
Climate change is fueling heatwaves, hurricanes and floods, gradually making certain places in the US challenging, if not outright miserable, to live in.
Scientists, and some members of the public, are starting to question where in the US will remain comfortable to call home.
The answer, broadly speaking, is north and maybe west. Florida has seen a population boom in recent decades but the southern portion of the state is on course to be submerged by rising seas. The Gulf coast will get supercharged hurricanes, while the south-west and south-east US will be baked by increasingly hostile heat.
“Areas towards the north and away from the ocean and that central corridor where you get tornadoes probably look best,” said Vivek Shandas, an expert on climate change’s impact on cities at Portland State University. Shandas recommends looking to live in a “band roughly above the 42nd parallel” – a line of latitude that divides New York and Pennsylvania and forms the southern borders of Oregon and Idaho.
Places close to a reliable source of water without being flood-prone as the seas rise are attractive, such as areas near the Great Lakes and the Pacific north-west. “Seattle doesn’t break 90F that often so it’ll be nothing like Phoenix in terms of tolerability of heat,” said Shandas. “Places like Portland, Oregon, and Boise, Idaho, will be relatively safeguarded, apart from a bit of wildfire smoke.”
There will be bastions elsewhere. “Cincinnati, for example, is surprisingly good,” said Shandas. “It’s close to the Great Lakes, away from hurricanes, away from the eastern seaboard. It will get more heatwaves, but then again we all will.”
Much of the east coast will look dicey if the seas rise at such a pace that they’ll be 6ft higher by the end of the century, but plenty will rest on local decisions made to shield residents from flooding. New York City, for example, is flanked by rising water and is already stiflingly hot in summer, but a multibillion-dollar strategy to build flood defenses and buy out vulnerable areas should help stave off the worst impacts.
Climate resiliency is a growing focus for many towns and cities that fret about expensive clean-up costs from disasters, shading people from the heat or dealing with an eroding tax base should residents decide to uproot and head somewhere safer.
The scope of these climate considerations is vast, touching on everything from transport links to the availability of flood insurance. Jesse Keenan, a climate adaptation expert at Harvard University, said that he likes Buffalo, New York, and Duluth, Minnesota, as climate refuges as they tick many of the appropriate boxes.
“Their sources of energy production are stable, they have cooler climates and they have access to plenty of fresh water,” Keenan said.
“They also have less vulnerability to forest fires, as compared to somewhere like the Pacific north-west. They also have a legacy of excess infrastructural capacity that allows them to diversify their economy in the future. Land prices are cheap and they have a relatively well-educated and skilled labor force.”
These safe havens are more of a fantasy wishlist for many moderate-to low-income people as property and rental values rise in desirable areas. Others won’t want to leave more vulnerable parts of the US due to more umbilical links, to family and jobs and a sense of home.
“As we saw after Hurricane Katrina and Hurricane Maria, communities that are able to move can do so, especially if family and friends do the same,” said Shandas. “Those with less resources are left behind.”
